First, I called in on Friday to make a reservation for 18 people and they were really accommodating to meet my needs. Although, we were 30 minutes late for our reservation they still seated us and provided us with amazing service.

I ordered the Filet Mignon and several of my party ordered the ribeye. We really enjoyed how juicy the steaks were and how it was nicely complimented with the potatoes. The only laughter we got from our meal was how sweet the carrots were. A little too sweet for our taste.

The drinks were ridiculously pricey and strong. But, if I am going to pay that much for a martini or Cosmo, they better be strong. 

Overall, I had a wonderful experience and we definitely enjoyed it. But, I wasn't knocked off my feet.
author: Tina K.

description:
Service was great as expected for the price paid, although it felt rushed near the end.  Got the most expensive 22oz cut of bone-in steak.  Cooked to my specification -medium rare. I was not expecting the sweetened carrot to be all cut up but it was for me - and it was fine. The smashed potato came with the dressings by request.  Salad - big portion to share.
Would I automatically think of this place if I hunger for steak again?  No.  I feel that I am paying for the location, which was elegant by itself and next to the hotel.
author: Drew B.

description:
We came here for Easter brunch because the hotel hyped it up.  What a disappointment!

We came for mid morning brunch.  Our three-course brunch (when there are only a limited number of options) shouldn't took over 2 hours because dishes came out at a snail's pace.  

 We were quickly seated at a nice table.  The busboy promptly served us coffee and water (upon request).  Nice touch by the busboy to put my 3-year-old's water in a plastic cup with a cap and straw. 

We ordered our brunch choices and the wait began.  Our waiter served our child's milk in a regular glass - no straw, no cover. Seriously?  We can't have brought the first kid into this restaurant.  We had to repeatedly flag waiters down for coffee refills. If you're going to charge $45 for a 3- course brunch, service should be better.  Waiters don't help each other out. 

The first courses came 45 minutes after we ordered. Lobster bisque was cold and the fruit plate was sad looking.  Waiter was about to serve my husband's appetizer to me and instead of walking around, he reached over me to serve the fruit plate.  I realize he said excuse my reach, but still, I think at a white tablecloth restaurant, the waiter should be willing to walk around.  Moreover, the waiter never came by to tell us what was taking so long.  

Main entrees were better, but came after another 30 min wait. Steak and pork chop entrees were perfectly cooked. Salmon salad was ok - wilted and overdressed greens; salmon did not have a nice sear on the outside.  Shrimp scampi was ok - shrimp looked good but pasta was oily and quite al dente.  Brunch took so long that my child was starting to rub his eyes and tell us he was tired.  

Dessert choices were limited - only 3 choices. We tried the amaretto cheesecake and coffee creme brûlée.  They were probably the best part of brunch.  

Service needs to be improved.  Our busboy was helpful and efficient but we only saw our waiter when we ordered and when he served the plates.  He never came back during our meal to check on us. Other waiters don't help out. We asked another waiter for coffee and he stopped at our table, but didn't even respond.  

If I ever return, I'd stick to steak and chops. I hope service improves.
author: Bruges L.

description:
Admittedly, if I was the one choosing/paying for a restaurant in San Francisco this would not be the place I would pick to eat. (There is nothing 'local' about this place. It feels like any generic high end steakhouse at any upscale mall) However, I was brought to dinner here as a business meeting and who am I to turn down a free steak?

I went with the $58 bone-in rib eye because the waiter said that was their specialty. A $60 steak SHOULD be amazing ... And it was. I have a big appetite and felt that after the fat was removed, the steak was on the small side. I did not feel full the way I do after eating at most steakhouses. For $60 this is a shame.

The steak itself was good. Well marbled, pretty tender and cooked perfectly to medium rare. The outside had a salty crust but the inside was soft and tender. Would I put it up there with the best steaks I've had? Yep. However, the smaller size for the price was a bit of a bummer.

The sides were lackluster. The mashed potatoes were typical. The giant phallic looking glazed carrot in the middle of the plate ... Random and strange. Didn't know quite what to make of that. Sourdough bread was kind of disappointing for a San Francisco staple.

I had scotch on the rocks with my steak but the person who took me here had a Martini and it looked huge!

The service was good but they had 2 waiters for a whole dining room and they were obviously overworked so getting their attention for a drink refill wasn't easy. The decor is dimly lit and lots of classy wood paneling. Very typical of any Capital Grille type of place you'd go to. 'Men's Club ambiance.

Overall, it was a damn good tasting steak. Wouldn't be my choice if I had to eat in SF because it is a bit generic. (Taditsch Grill or Scomas or Gary Danko would be my choice) However, for steak ... Its better than going to a Ruth Chris and good for business meetings.
author: E T.

description:
I'm all carnivore and a steak Connoisseur.   Lets get to the point:  Got the $72 porterhouse - cooked medium.    It was slightly over seasoned for my taste.. typical old school style, but it was cooked to perfection.   The cut looked more like 20oz, not the advertised 28oz.    I was ok with that as long as the steak delivered  which it did.     The presentation could have been a little better.

Food was 4.5 stars..  

On the other hand our service was excellent.   Right off the bat I told our waiter to bring everything out as fast as possible.  The salad came out within 4 minutes, the appetizer was out within 6 minutes,  and half way though our salads our steaks came out.   

Our jaws dropped.. we were not expecting the steaks for 45 minutes, but we asked and they delivered exactly as requested.    Our waiter and the staff were very attentive.

5+ stars for the service..

The atmosphere does not promote romance.. so not the best place for a date.. but if you want a nice steak, this place ranks high.
author: Danny D.

description:
Bob's Steak & Chop House exists solely for 2 Martini lunches.   That isn't to say that Martinis are the only reason to come to Bob's, but if you're going to have lunch here (preferably a business lunch where somebody else picks up the tab) you should definitely start it off with a Martini.

I opted for a Hendrick's Gin Martini, up.   They gave me a couple of olives and the pour was very very generous.    It's pricey, at $18 a pop, but it'll definitely get your creative juices flowing for your afternoon meetings.   My coworker had eaten here a few times and suggested we go with the country fried steak, so we obliged.   The meat was tasty though I think next time I come here I'll just go for the meat, straight up, and forgo the deep fried preparation.   The dish was well prepared so please understand there are no complaints, but I realized then and there that I prefer my meat, lightly salted witha generous portion of pepper, bloody and certainly not drowned in A1.   That's how I roll...

Hmmm.... thinking about it now, I could go for a long lunch and a couple of Martinis right about now.
author: David O.

description:
When you think of a steakhouse in a major city where you expect to pay $50-$80 for a steak without starch- you expect perfection in food and service.

Well what a disappointment this place was. We love the SF Omni so whenever heading to the wine country we stay here and since our flight was delayed we opted for Bob's.

The waiter was very miserable which kind of sets the mood all wrong, the food was taking forever- I mean there are 4 tables with clients in the entire restaurant- so not sure what was going on. Then we get our filet that is burned on the outside so we send it back only to get even worse cut 20 minutes later at which point we said thank you but no thank you. At this point it is 10pm mind you. The manager comes over with a lame 'I am sorry about that" and walks off.

The other food was decent but not fantastic for this class of a restaurant. The bus boy was the best part of our experience.
author: Gabriela S.

description: I have eaten prime rib all over the world.  Without a doubt, this was the worst I have ever had.   Two thumbs way down.
author: Kent N.

description:
Excellent service that was attentive, without being smothering.  

Had the 12 ounce NY Strip, medium rare, and that was excellent.  

Couldn't categorize this as an elite steak house, but it's a solid 4 star restaurant. 

Like some other reviewers, I just don't get the glazed carrot, but it was good.
author: Erik B.

description:
Came here for a business lunch and got the burger (steak takes too long). It was fine, thought it would be a lot better being prime and all - tasted a little too beefy, not as richly flavored. 

Also I'm not a fan of brioche type buns, a little too sweet and thick. Fries were good, no problems there, and service was pretty friendly.
author: Philip L.

description:
Its the, "not worth you time hotel restaurant." 

I came here on a business lunch and had the Bone-in Rib-Eye. It was really good but everything else was a disappointment. We spent two hours here and I only got one refill on my coffee as we never saw the server. I hope I never have to come back.
author: Justin S.

description:
Took a client for lunch here last week, he was craving steak and it's the only "steak place" open for lunch without a reservation downtown.  We walked up to the maitre'd stand where a manager and a waiter were talking.  They looked at us, turned around and walked away into the restaurant, without acknowledging us... After a couple of minutes the waiter came back, seated us like it was an inconvenience, and again didn't say a word.

The food is OK, decent steak, but it costs about 25% more than it tastes like it should...  Come here if you don't mind paying a premium for rude and generally incompetent service.
author: Alex H.

description:
I would have given BoB's 5 Stars if it weren't for the server from hell!

My wife and I are regular patrons of BoB's when we're in the City. Normally, the servers are on point. However, on Valentine's Day we and our goods friends decided to spend the night in the City and have dinner at BoB's. The ambiance was perfect as always. We arrived early and decided to have drinks at the bar. Alejandra, our server was on point. She provided to upmost customer service. 

The host indicated that our booth was ready. We got comfortable and within 5 min, our server came over and introduced herself. We ordered some more drinks and crab cakes for 4. When our order arrived, the plating was incorrect. She brought over 2 single plates with the crab cakes and 1 large plate with 2 cakes ????????? Then when we placed our main order, we asked to split our salad. The salad came in 1 bowl... Not split! This type of service was experienced all night. The problem here was that our server was not listening to our requests. And, if the kitchen plated wrong, then she should have made the correction before presenting it to the guests. 

The food was good as always. However, I gave BoB's an "F" for the service rendered.
author: Angel A.

description: One of our best all-time meals ever!  The food was unimprovable and the service was uncommonly friendly and efficient.  Shelley was one of the friendliest and wonderful waitresses ever.  My 13 year old declared tonight's dinner her all time favorite!
author: David D.

description: The best steak that I've ever had. It's sad to know that I'll never have a better piece of meet in my life.
author: Travis R.

description: Decent food, pretty tasty, but prices are ridiculous. $6 coffee or juice does not make sense. And it's not Starbucks cappuccino, bit a simple black coffee.
author: Renats S.

description:
Not sure what the big deal is about this place.  They had reservations available every 15 minutes on a Saturday night, that should have been my first warning.  I had what was probably the worst Dirty Martini ever, olives were way too salty and threw off the entire drink.  We sent back our side dishes, the creamed spinach had a layer of crusty cheese and the spinach was cold, the Brussels sprouts were very chewy, like eating rubber bands. I would expect more especially since this is in the lobby of the Omni Hotel. 

In case you can't tell from my review, I will not be going back nor will I be recommending this place to anyone.
author: Tom C.

description: This review is for the corner bar inside the Omni. Super sweet server and bartender. Mixed drinks are pricey though. I love Moscow Mules, but this place made a nasty one. Take my word for it. Yack! Atmosphere is cozy and warm and there is plenty of view on this little corner. Also ordered dessert. Portions are enormous!!!! My friend ordered the carrot cake wedge and it was seriously equivalent to a quarter of a cake! I had a slice of key lime pie which was twice the size of most servings. Wasn't that great. Too sweet.
author: Peggy K.

description:
We were in the city for our annual Christmas shopping spree. We made reservations for our party of 6 all hankering for a stellar SF dinner at a famous steak house.
Arriving we were seated and our waitress took our drink order and provided the menu. Upon looking through the menu we were told that the price was in direct proportion to the quality of beef that they served, Most of it was suppose to be prime, and it may have been. Had it been the best beef I have ever had, I would have to say that sadly it was not. Our party ordered a good cross section, from the New York steak to their Tomahawk cut ( which was a rib eye with the  long bone still on it, therefore looking like a Tomahawk)  marketing strategy giving them an extra 15 bucks in hype.
Between the add on's for side dishes, creamed corn and creamed spinach, the average tab per person was about $ 90 a person. Add the wine and  you have a couple of months mortgage payment.
All in all it was a decent dining experience, was it the best I have had, no sad ly  but it was  a decent meal, decent service, decent ambiance. Would we return, maybe after checking out over 3000 other places in the City first.
author: Matt G.

description:
I went here last night after having avoided it for years because of a bad experience 5 years ago. But I knew Bob's had a good reputation and I was willing to check it out again.

I shared a Tomahawk steak with a friend and it made me wish we had never evolved from the Stone Age. Why can't we just live the simple cave-dweller lifestyle and chew on Tomahawk steaks all day? Well, for one thing, it is doubtful that one could reliably get the fire up to the temperature required to roast this thing to perfect, as they are somehow able to do at Bob's.

Bob has redeemed himself. Carrots were excellent, mashed potatoes and onion rings not so much. Wait staff are actually professionals, not actors or artists trying to just pay rent, Just the right amount of table visits from the various staff, I think the experience was enhanced by the fact that it was relatively empty and not noisy.
author: Phil W.

description:
One of the best pieces of tenderloin I've ever had.

Bone in "cote du boeuf" rib eye very good and had great marbled fat.

smashed potatoes are super smooth and well seasoned.

potatoes with sauteed onions and peppercorn gravy was crunchy and well balanced.  

whole piece of glazed carrot was extremely soft and smooth.  nice acidic balance to the fatty meat and heavy potatoes.

service extremely excellent.

the runner's were chinese and hooked us up with some bread to go.  

bread was some of the best I've had as well!
author: Kevin L.

description:
Father's Day brought me to Bob's Steakhouse at the Omni Hotel in the heart of the SF Financial District. First thing, go on a Sunday because you do not have to pay for parking. The meters are free even in the yellow zones, so I parked across the street for free and did not need a parking lot or valet parking which is at the hotel entrance on California Street.
Bob's décor is traditional old school steakhouse, lots of dark wood and leather chairs. The overhand light fixtures offer a little light but otherwise dim setting. The host and waitress were excellent and very accommodating and pleasant. The entire wait staff was top notch. When we arrived for our reservations at 5:30 it was not busy for a Sunday. 
I started with the fried calamari ($14.00) which was very good. I also ordered my standard Jack and Coke ($14.00) they served me up a double size not your puny single. I ordered the Kansas City cut steak (bone-in) $53.00. The order comes with a huge honey glazed carrot and choice of potato. I chose the "smashed potato which is your mashed potato. Dinner is also served with warm round of bread. We ordered two sides, sautéed mushrooms (delicious and large) and streamed broccoli (giant size). Sides are good for 3 people. Wife had the broiled salmon, son had the shrimp scampi with enormous prawns. Both enjoyed their meals.
I also had a glass of house merlot with my steak which ran me around $27.00 but was excellent. They have a $25.00 corkage fee.
No room for dessert but I was very pleased with Bob's Steakhouse.
The lobby of the Omni Hotel is very nice also.
author: jack d.

description:
Good steak, slow service. The ribeye, smashed potatoes, glazed carrot and bread were all very good. The creme brûlée wasn't up to par -- I ate about 1/4 and decided it wasn't worth the calories. 

I dined alone and it took them 1 1/2 hours to serve me. Either they were understaffed or their servers didn't want to waste their energies on a single guest with a paltry $75 ticket. Not overly impressed for the price.
author: Roy C.

description:
I recently had a business lunch at Bob's Steak and Chop House in the Omni Hotel. I(t was as close as a mortal might come to the "perfect lunch." 

Because Bob's doesn't pander to what I call the "popular pablum press," it doesn't get the kind of attention that several other steak houses receive, particularly the cluster of them along the 101/Van Ness corridor.  

That afternoon I found out why:  Bob's doesn't need to promote their food.  On a nondescript Tuesday afternoon, the place was jammed, not a single table available.  Fortunately, my host had made a reservation well in advance and there was no wait.  

Upon being seated I quickly realized one thing:  this is a "guy's place."  The decor, setting and feel of the room was definitely "masculine."  While I may not be PC for noting this neither am I blind and brain-dead; the place has a "red meat/blue blood" look and feel.  Beautiful woods, thick crisp linens, elegant crystal chandeliers...it just felt stalwart, honest and forthright.  Elegant, without pretense.  

Service was great.  By the time my butt hit the chair we were served water and warm (amazing!) bread and fresh rich butter were brought to the table.  Our glasses (tea and lemonade) were refilled with stealth professionalism and the wait staff was very helpful, particularly in making selections from the menu.

I wasn't particularly, hungry, but wanted to taste the beef that Bob's is so famous for (Kansas in origin I believe).  The chef must have anticipated a palate like mine - offering up a crisp green salad overwhelmed (yum!) with slices of rib eye steak and blue cheese.  The dish was perfect: the greens were lightly teased with a vinaigrette that had just the perfect acidity to match up with the beef and cheese.  I asked for more of the amazing bread and butter (seemed like just-churned) and sent the plate back immaculate.  Bread dish & butter also unburdened of evert morsel. 

What made this otherwise simple and basic dish so memorable was the beef, however.  Generous slices of 3/8" thick slices (perfect for the dish) were done to perfection - medium rare inside and blackened on the outside.  The cut was rich, flavorful and tender.  The mouthfeel was ideal - full of meaty texture without a fiber of grisly resistance.  And most important:  the beef stood on its own; there was little or no residual spice, salt or flavor enhancer.  Thanks God!

My fellow diners were equally pleased.  One, deciding to be a contrarian, went for the fish tacos (halibut).  The presentation was beautiful and the flavors were perfect (yes, I begged a bite...too enticing to resist!).  

We finished with coffee, which was fresh-brewed and refilled without ceremony or disruption.  

So, what's a "perfect lunch"?  it is a lunch that went so smoothly that it was almost forgettable, but so tasty that the memory lingers for over a week later.  Only one warning:  this is probably not the place to take your kale mongering food toady deb friends.  While the menu is eclectic, Bob's knows why it was placed on this planet...and they make not apologies for bringing-on a VERY upscale "red-meat" experience (RME).  And while I don't frequently indulge in RME, I am not going to compromise when I do. And Bob's compromises nothing...not even the butter!
author: Bill R.

description: Been 6 years since eating here and happy to report that Bob's is still a great place for steak. We each had the largest fillet mignon which was HUGE and cooked to perfection. If you want a superb steak, Bob's is the place to go. Salad, potato, and signature carrot very good, too. Service was cordial and attentive. The entire experience deserves 5 stars.
author: IQuack D.

description:
I hate to agree with the many negative people on here but I was pretty disappointed with my overall experience here. 

Service was not attentive. 
Steak was good but I think its on par but more expensive than most top notch steak houses.
glazed carrot was not good... kind of reminded me of a carrot that had been dipped in a fireball (the cinammon shot)
mashed potatoes was pretty decent
spinach and mushrooms... just wasn't well done. 

All in all I would rather spend my money at bobo's or alexanders where you get what you pay for.
author: James H.

description:
We came here on Sunday night which might be the reason they were not busy. The restaurant has a nice decor and the staff working there from waiters to busboy are very attentive and our water glass were always filled up. We tried the onion rings and they were great! gotta be the best I ever tasted. I also ordered the lobster bisque an it was delicious! The steaks were great! 
PRIME RIBEYE 
PRIME "COTE DE BOEUF" BONE-IN RIBEYE
PRIME FILET MIGNON 
PRIME PORTERHOUSE 

All taste great! Love it! They also have the pickle jar on each table where you can taste but we find it too sour and a bit salty. Overall a great experience and the location is great! Valet parking at the hotel and it cost about $15 dollars. I think from now on I will come to Bob's more often than Morton's.
author: William C.

description:
This place is disappointing for its price point. I was here for lunch had the salmon salad, my friend had a steak and both of us were underwhelmed.  

The only redeeming quality of this place is in its convenience if you are a hotel guest.
author: Mustafa O.

description: Service and food was great. We absolutely loved it! Classic dishes with outstanding service. We brought our 4 year old, which was not an issue at all and they have great kids menues.
author: Ronnie H.

description: Bob's had a nice quaint ambiance. Dining hall separate from the bar withing the Omni Hotel. With a ground floor view in San Francisco's financial district of well aged towering architecture. The table servers were friendly and we'll attentive. I tried the Kansas Ribeye which was excellent. And ordered the Fillet Mignon which was very light and well cooked. Skillet potatoes were seasoned well with a slight crisp and a full  bodied peppercorn brown gravy. Even the carrot had a nice glaze with a hint of cinnamon. Bravo and well played.
author: CJ S.

description:
We came here to celebrate our 1 year anniversary. We never do fancy so this was a treat. I usually never order meat as my meal choice but here it seemed the right thing to do, as my hubby encouraged stepping outside my usual choices....I did order the tomato, red onion & blue cheese salad (which could have just been my meal in itself)...It was amazing! Then I branched out and ordered the filet mignon and of course I needed it well done--No pink/red please :).
That being said it came out charred :(  it tasted of justy burnt meat, I felt so bad that I didnt trust my hubby when warning me..i should have ordered med-well. You live and you learn!
Onto dessert; the Omni Hotel provided us with a free dessert for our celebration and we were given a sampler: Mocha Cheesecake, Triple Chocolare cake & Carrot Cake--Carrot was the best hands down.
We were seated near a birthday party that were really loud...Wished that we could have been seated on the area of private booths for some quiet.
Our server was SUPER sweet and very attentive.
author: Crystal O.

description: Always a classy experience at Bob's.  We always request a booth when we go here and we usually get a great and secluded table.  Love the bread and hunk of butter they give you while you wait for your food.  The food is excellent, their ribeyes are the best!  One of the best in the city.  The fries that came with the meal were a bit overlooked this time but the carrots were so yummy!  Next  time I will stick with the smashed potatoes.
author: Marylouise R.

description: The steak is perfect. Great service, nice old jazz.  Classic and great
author: Maureen D.

description:
This restaurant is in the very beautiful Omni Hotel. My wife and I were with two very good friends after a full day in San Francisco. We used Valet, which i would recommend since the city has so many street parking rules. Bob's even discount's it to $15 if you eat there.
 We started with the Calamari. For me, it was a bit to chewy, nevertheless, still very good.  Moving with the beautifully presented Bleu Cheese salad. I loved the unexpected combinations of bleu cheese eggs and pecans. WOW! All the while they would bring endless delicious french bread warmly sliced with delicious butter.  

Our server then asked if we were ready to order. Very polite and very knowledgeable. Undecided of which steak I was going to order, i kept looking at their simple yet full of options menu. The waitress then mentioned that they also had in the restaurant a very special steak, Kobe steak. The meat is generally considered to be a delicacy, renowned for its flavor, and tenderness. So that's what I had. Let me put it this way, it's the best steak I have EVER had. So juicy, not overly seasoned. The steak had so much natural flavor. They actually just served it on a cutting board. Paired it with a delicious Cab, and I had the best steak dinner of my life. 
We asked to complement the Chef and he came out. He said it's a real treat for him to prepare this kind of steak and took a lot of pride in it. His name is Santana Diaz, and he used to be Sacramento Kings Maloof brothers' personal chef. He gave me his card to call him to make sure he had Kobe steaks whenever we stopped by again. It was a pretty cool move.
By the way, the desert is also humongous. Next time i will pass on the dessert, it's just too much goodness!!!!!!
author: Angel M.

description: My wife and I have been celebrating our birthdays here for the last 8 years and would never consider any other place. From the wonderful hot bread, complementary marinated pickles & peppers to the perfectly cooked prime steaks and deserts, all have been worthy of a birthday celebration. Every year they welcome us back with superb service.
author: David R.

description: This is more of a hotel restaurant than American Steakhouse.  While the decor and location are great, the food, service, and wine list are below average for a steakhouse.  The quality of our meal was well below average for prime beef.  The steaks had very little natural flavor and were poorly seasoned.  On an upside, they were cooked to the proper temperature.  In addition to the main attraction, the sides were bland as well.  The wine list is very poorly done with a handful of the usual corporate selections and very few interesting producers.  Again, I would have expected more.
author: Daniel B.

description:
I came here for my brother's birthday dinner. We had 5 people and it was all of our first time going! Someone said they liked the steak here better then Morton's! I must admit, it was pretty juicy!



Ambiance: 
I felt like I was back in time in an old Italian nice restaurant for some reason. It wasn't too busy, very clean, and a bit cold with the AC on. It was also dim and made me sleepy haha. 



Order: 
Jar of pickled peppers and pickles - I had a piece of the pickle and it was more on the bland side.

Fried Calamari - Huge appetizer portion with cocktail sauce. My party liked it, it wasn't oily or too fried. I thought it was yummy.

Bread appetizer - I didn't get to try any but my brother said it was hard on the outside crust so it looked like it was tough to cut a piece and to chew. But he liked it with the butter!

Spinach Salad - So good! It was well dressed and tasty! Generous portion too!

Broiled Salmon - It was a generous portion of Salmon. I gave half of my piece away! The sauce on top with the salmon tasted good with the mash side. The whole seasoned carrot was sooo good. Everyone keeps telling me how good the carrot was and I must agree! Mashed potatoes was so good with everything! Especially with the creamed corn in it.

Prime Ribeye - I got to try a piece of the steak and it was very juicy for a medium rare cooked piece. I enjoyed my bite for sure. Grilled onions wasn't a hit for us. We all didn't really like the onions.

Creamed Corn - I love corn! It was very creamy, more on the creamier side which I didn't mind. 

Creamed Spinach - There was cheese in it which I love! As time went on with the dinner, this dish got cold and the cheese hardened so it was so tasty after about 20 minutes. Must eat this dish quick. It was also very thick. Not going to order this again if I go back. 

Marbled Chocolate Amaeretto Cheesecake - I loved the almonds on this large piece of cheesecake! I got to share it with 3 people because it was a ginormous!



Set back:
Our waiter took a very long time to check up on us after appetizer, dinner, and dessert. We had a 7pm dinner that lasted until 10pm. I would say a quarter of the time, we were waiting to be helped by our waiter. He was very nice though. 

Great food! I would like to try other dishes the next time I come back!
author: Jenny H.

description: I've been there twice now and had great food and great fun each time. The setting is old fashioned. The drinks are strong. The steaks are well executed. And for good measure, there is a jar of pickles on the table.
author: Bob R.

description:
Had dinner here for the first time with my husband and a friend on a weeknight. 

SERVICE. Attentive, non-obtrusive and friendly. My iced tea was always being filled without me noticing it. Our server gave us great recommendations which we followed. We were not disappointed.

FOOD. Loved the warm bread and generous amount of butter. I ordered the bone-in Cote de Boeuf ribeye upon the recommendation of the server. And my, it was excellent! It was tasty, tender, and cooked perfectly medium-well the way I requested. I liked the marbled meat with a little fat which made it even tastier. I didn't think I could finish it at first because it was huge, but I did! The steak came with a big, tender glazed carrot and mashed potatoes. The caramelized carrot hit home. I don't know how to explain it, except that the taste made me think of and feel like...Christmas. Perhaps there was a dash of cinnamon in the carrot glaze, the same kind of cinnamon sprinkled on hot cocoa I used to drink growing up every Christmas morning. The "smashed" potatoes were great, too, although I didn't finish it because I focused more on the yummy steak. We also ordered the crab cakes which we happily devoured, and desserts (bread pudding and creme brulee). We enjoyed the desserts, too, but between the three of us, we left a few dessert bites on the plates because the entrees were so big that we were so full by the time we hit our third course. 

AMBIANCE. The restaurant is inside the beautiful Omni Hotel. Walking in, you will right away feel the upscale ambiance of it all. This is the place to eat when you want to celebrate, to treat yourself, or to feel special just because. 

In summary, I would go back to Bob's in a heartbeat. This has now become my new go-to place for steak. It's not cheap, but I always believe that you get what you pay for. And in this case, the attentive service, the delicious food, and the classy ambiance definitely made it all worth it.
author: Algo R.

description: I stay at the Omni 5-6x per year and sometimes eat here for convenience sake.    The service is good, but the overall quality is well below the food prices.  I'd summarize it and say it's a nice hotel restaurant with nice hotel restaurant food, but certainly nothing distinct or comparable to a fine steak house.
author: Rick R.

description: Just finished Thanksgiving dinner at Bobs and we have to say, it was great!  The meal was delicious and very ample and our waiter, George, couldn't have been any better.  Would HIGHLY recommend this place for any holiday dinner. Will definitely go back next year or sooner!
author: Michael H.

description:
Do not waste even an expense account on this white table cloth joint.
Others have remarked they found the room  half empty. That's the first clue I should have known better than to walk in.  Wildly expensive for mediocre or worse food:  eg. unexceptional burger: $19, ordered by my companion.   I ordered the crab Cobb salad.  The crab--way past its use-by date-- smelled faintly of ammonia.  Asked waiter to switch it for the grilled chicken Cobb salad.  The new salad arrived about a second later. It was flavorless, weirdly rigid, seemed put together days before. The cubed chicken had that flat taste and texture of processed--no evidence of grilling. It was served  over-chilled and on an ice cold plate.  
Service was polished and perfect.
author: Jacqui O.

description:
On Saturday, 4/26/14, my girlfriend and I ate at Bob's Steak and Chops for dinner. Bob's is connected to the Omni hotel. Bob's is a restaurant that started in Dallas. They have a good reputation for serving various cuts of prime Texas style beef. 

Atmosphere/Décor:

The restaurant is really nice. It kind of reminds me of a combination between Morton's steakhouse and Alfred's steakhouse but Bob's is more upscale in my opinion. The tables and chairs are really nice. They also have booth seating available. The lighting of the restaurant is low to dim which creates more of an intimate setting.

Food: 

When we first sat down the waitress brought out a jar full of pickles and peppers. I read some yelp reviews that say the pickles and peepers are very good. My girlfriend and I didn't try either. I just didn't trust the fact that there's a possibility of other previous diners reaching in and touching the jars, pickles and peppers not being replaced to fresh ones. I decided to go with the Coute De Beef bone in ribeye 22 oz steak. I ordered the steak medium. I always order my steaks medium but If I'm eating Kobe beef I'll order it medium rare. My Coute De Beef came out well done! I was disappointed. I took a few bites and it tasted really good but it was overcooked. I was so hungry I thought about just eating it and not sending it back but I thought since I'm paying almost $60 bucks for this steak it should be cooked to my liking. The waitress came by and said "how does everything taste?" I said, "Good, but my steak is overcooked, it's well done." She took a look at my steak and said, "Oh yeah, that's way overcooked. Let me take that steak back and I'll have them cook you another one." While I was waiting for them to cook my new steak, my girlfriend was enjoying her steak. The manager came over to our table and apologized and said my steak will be coming out shortly. About 10 minutes later my steak came out. I started eating the steak and it still wasn't cooked to medium. It was a mixture of medium well and well done throughout the steak. I didn't send the steak back for the 2nd time, I ate it. The steak came with garlic smashed potatoes and a huge long carrot with some type of cinnamon syrup glaze. The smashed potatoes were excellent. They had a ton of flavor. I didn't care for the carrot. The sweet glaze was a little too much for me. It didn't go well or compliment the steak and smashed potatoes.
  
My girlfriend ordered the 9 oz filet mignon. She liked it a lot. She ordered her steak medium. It came out a true medium well. She wished her steak was medium but she still enjoyed it. She loved the smashed potatoes as well but didn't care for the carrot either.
 
Our waitress came over to our table and told us that dessert is on the house because of my overcooked steak. I passed on dessert even though it was free but my girlfriend ordered the banana rum bread pudding topped off with a scoop of vanilla ice cream. My girlfriend said the dessert was rich and tasted good. 
Maybe the Executive or main chef wasn't there that night but every steak should be cooked perfectly at a steak house. There's no excuse for an under cooked or overcooked steak.
  
Service:

Our waitress was great! She was very attentive and when I asked her about the history of Bob's Steaks and Chops, she seemed to know a lot about the history. She explained to me where Bobs' started at and where the various locations are. She was very knowledgeable.
 
Overall:
 
Bob's Steaks and Chops is a good steak restaurant. They serve high quality prime beef steaks. Even if you overcook a prime steak it's still going to taste good because prime beef is considered top 1%. I would have given Bob's a 4 but the fact my steak was overcooked, technically twice, I had to take off 2 stars. If you're staying at the Omni Hotel and you are craving a flavorful steak, then Bob's is a good restaurant to dine at. I would go back to Bob's and give it another shot and order a different steak but not anytime soon. It's hard for me to give steakhouses high ratings because after eating at Alexander's steakhouse you've have experienced nothing but the best. Other steakhouses don't compare and can't compete with Alexander's.
author: David R.

description: I stayed in the Omni and went to this place for breakfast.  I had an omelet with bacon, onions, and cheddar cheese.  It was close to great and may have been the best omelet I had in SF, which was surprising.  The potatoes were good, but slightly overcooked.  The fruit was very fresh.
author: Bob B.

description: "We're out of the Seafood of the Day", huh? San Francisco is on the water, right? You have plenty of fish around and you offer only one item? For hotel guests who don't want a side of beef while sitting in the bar, the choices are limited. The food was pleasant and service was fine. Nothing to write home about.
author: Matt T.

description:
Nice steakhouse and conveniently located next to the lobby of the Omni Hotel where we were staying. Steak is cooked well, but I've had better. The price here is great considering how many steakhouses make you pay extra for side dishes; Bob's gives you glazed carrots and mashed potatoes along with your order of steak. Complimentary round sourdough loaf was warm and tasty as were the pickles in the jar that sits in the middle of every table. 

There were three of us and we ordered two ribeyes (split one entree between two girls) For an appetizer we each had our own salad. Skipped on dessert. For three people, it came out to be $140 with tip. Not bad. We also had a one year old with us and they staff was very accommodating. Service was excellent and staff was very friendly and attentive. Overall I would come back just because the atmosphere is calm and not pretentious or stuffy.
author: Lilee N.

description:
Had the blue cheese salad - an appetizer - and it was SO good. And the perfect size.
Classy place, great service, iced tea is fresh brewed. Old fashioned.
author: Andrew K.

description: What can I say that hasn't already been said. Simply my favorite upscale steakhouse.  The steaks are of the highest quality and the service attentive. Trust your waiters recommendation selection.
author: Rich G.

description: Fab Steak Salads and Dry Martinis, the lunch service is always stellar and I always get a table with or without a reservation.
author: Kayla B.

description:
Decent steak and a little kitsch.

I was on a quick trip to San Francisco recently and stayed at the Omni. I figured I'd keep it simple and dine at Bob's, the restaurant at the Omni. Nice friendly staff (mostly), pretty good steak, pretty good wine list (including a Chateau Montelena Cab by the glass, yum). I had a nice Kansas City Strip, done nicely at medium rare. I had a wedge salad, nicely dressed, along with the aforementioned Chateau Montelena cab. Add on a baked potato and you've got the perfect, quintessential steak meal.

So the kitsch? yeah, a jar of garlic pickles and pickled soft red peppers on each table.I had the crispiest, tastiest dill pickle I had in years. 

Fine dining, no. Best SF has to offer, not close. Fun if you just enjoy it, yes.
author: Bill B.

description:
To be honest, I haven't been back here in a while so I'm basing this review on memory from about a year ago. 

I came here with a bunch of friends as a guy's night out. A bunch of guys and red meat and wine. Not a bad way to spend an evening. I remember getting the ribeye which was cooked just the way I liked -- medium rare. Well cooked and lots of good flavor.

For sides, I actually went healthier with some fresh broccoli. While I don't mind them steaming the vegetables, it'd be nicer if they cooked them a bit longer. Broccoli was a bit tough and could have been a lot tender.

All together, accounting for the food, couple bottles of nice wine, tip and tax, we probably paid around $50~ per person. A bit pricey but nice for special occasions.

Overall, this place is not a bad choice if you're looking for a steakhouse. Parking can be a pain since it's downtown. However, the ambiance is quiet and low lighting.
author: Jonathan L.

description: I got 9oz filet mignon medium and fiancé got 12 oz filet mignon done medium.  It was cooked perfect.  The outside had a nice crisp and the inside was tender. The carrot was like candied yam but carrot style.  I got the smash potato but I preferred the baked potato that my fiancé got. They slathered cheese, bacon, chives and sour cream :P
author: Grace C.

description:
One of my FAV restaurants!!!

They have 1,000 Open Table points for early dinners.

Fridays are free corkage.  And they don't have a split plate charge.

Staff is a bit "asian" here which seems a bit off for such a classy restaurant, but they're very nice, prompt, and helpful.

RIBEYE!!!!! YUM~! Crabcakes YUMM~!  Desserts...just okay, but they're massive, so share!
author: Janet L.

description:
Bob's is the best. Better than perhaps all the rest.

I really have an appreciation for a well executed dining experience. I am using the Yelp forum to celebrate my experience for the most paramount of dining experiences, the full course steak meal. If you cannot recognize my vast knowledge for the experience I may have to club you

I would like to meet Bob and shake his hand. I have not visited locations in Texas yet I feel compelled to shake the man's hand. I visited for dinner with a friend who was staying at the Omni and we had a succulent meal. Delicious. I liked the giant carrot (pictured) that was served with my steak. Somehow this is brilliant move and the texture of the carrot complemented my steak nicely. I had twelve ounce filet mignon cooked medium-rare. Delicious. No sauce only coarsely ground black pepper for myself.  

The decor is impeccable with wood paneling and nicely appointed tables. If you visit Bob's Steak and Chop House and are somehow disappointed, color me surprised because I believe I had an excellent experience.
author: James D.

description:
Consistently best steakhouse in downtown, period.

Located on the first floor in the Omni. Nice steakhouse ambiance.

The hosts are first class and very accommodating.

Appetizers are great, but I recommend the Calamari and Shrimp Cocktail. The Calamari are always cooked to perfection and though I rarely put lemon on calamari I works perfect here. The preparation allows for the lemon not to overwhelm. Regarding the shrimp cocktail, the presentation is a little different; comes with the cocktail sauce on the shrimp. I prefer it on the side. Regardless, ask for extra horseradish. Why make a bid deal over calamari and a shrimp cocktail - they do it right.

The Filets and Strips are always incredibly flavorful; great cuts of prime beef and cooked to perfection. My recommendation - the Porterhouse. It is outstanding. 

The Service is excellent. Ask for Moe and tell him Anthony sent you. He will take care of you. (And, if you're on a tight schedule let him know so he can expedite your order.)

Side recommendation - I'm not a huge fan of the "famous" cinnamon carrot. My friends all agree. The cinnamon overwhelms the steak - but try it if you must. I recommend that you get the carrot - but ask them to leave off the cinnamon glaze.

Enjoy.
author: Anthony G.

description:
I will never go back or recomend. The city has so much to offer that there is no need to go to a place where the service could no be worst and the waiter so rude. 
They took forever to serve our food which by the way was from 1 to 10 only 8. But the service was bad I will never recomend or go back.
author: Rocio Q.

description:
Seriously the best steakhouse I have ever been to. 

Morton's Steakhouse and Ruth's Chris have nothing on this place. Hands down this was the best dining experience ever. The entrees here are beyond delicious! Namely, the filet mignon.  

I also highly recommend coming here for special occasions. We came here to celebrate my parents anniversary. The service was outstanding. At the end of our meal, our waiter brought out the biggest ice cream sundae I have ever seen. It was not only the biggest one I've seen, but the best I have ever tasted. They also gave my parents a warming anniversary card signed by all their staff members and a cute box of macaroons to go! 

Our dining experience here was unforgettable. We will definitely be back :)
author: Nadia N.

description: Amazing. Perfect food, dining, service. This is my go to for special occasions. Their steaks melt in your mouth. The shrimp trio for an appetizer is almost a meal it's self. The dining room is very elegant leading into the Omni hotel. The sports bar is also very nice for downtown San Francisco.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
Having been to about 100 steakhouses over the course of my life, they all start to blend together. I mean, as long as you know how to cook a steak and can make good mashed potatoes, you're pretty much guaranteed three stars. Then, it all comes down to décor and service and dessert. Well, with all of that said, Bob knows how to cook a steak. The filet was very moist and tender. The mashed potatoes were very solid. And even the carrot they serve in between was quite good.

Service was fine, granted he kept dripping the wine all over my setting. And décor, while dated, seemed to add to the charm of the place in some bizarre sort of way. Sort of like a cute elderly person going through their second childhood. But in restaurant form.

And as for dessert, the bread pudding was just okay. Not terrible, but I have had much better. So, as I insinuated from the beginning... Three stars.
author: Ari H.

description:
I used to crave for Bob's Cobb with crab, but I no longer do.  Went there for lunch, Jane got Bob's Cobb with crab, had a bite of hers, it was just alright.  I got the seafood of the day, blackened halibut with papaya salsa, the mash potato was awesome, the fish was just alright.  Chris got the scallops entree, had a bite of hers, it was just alright.  The scallops were a bit overcooked and firmer than my fish.  Jeff got the ribeye special, he asked for medium well, came out mooing on his plate, he was being polite and didn't send it back to the kitchen....

Service was friendly, but it was way too slow.  Desserts were massive but ordinary, unimpressive and again, came out super slow.  If we knew it would take that long, we would've skipped dessert.
author: Gigi T.

description: Highly recommend the Roasted Duck with the green peppercorn sauce. Very delectable! The Rack of Lamb is also delicious. Service was impeccable.
author: Taylor M.

description: I have dined at the original Bobs in Dallas for several years.  ...........  And this was such a let down.   Just not the same.  The service and food were good and most likely better than most in the SF area but nothing compared to Dinning at the original location.
author: Martin P.

description: Came for breakfast and was not disappointed. From food to service-exceptional! All of the wait staff was super friendly and went out of there way to make me feel comfortable. I'm 7.5 months pregnant-from the man who filled my water to the waitress-they were so sweet and accommodating. Not to mention the pancakes were the best I've ever had-I came back again the next a.m. The waitress even brought out a little fruit smoothie cup at the end on the house. I could tell the staff got along well! The manager also came to check on everything and see how everything was, which is always nice. As a sidenote, the man who kept filling my water told me about his experience with his 5 month baby and this made my trip. Even the man putting out silverware said "good morning ma'am". Overall, the little details on with service and food (e.g. Mint on fruit bowl, powder sugar on pancakes, fruit smoothie on the house) made my experience so pleasant and would highly recommend. Similar to 4 seasons service but even friendlier!
author: Jamie G.

description: A buddy of mine that lives in the city met up with me to have a drink here since I was staying at Omni.  I don't usually give low ratings but come on, service was just crap.  The only reason why I even gave a 2 star was for the Mac and cheese we ordered to eat on while drinks shots.  The waitress was just simply rude and we tried to be friendly by making small talks but nothing. Kind of like a robot.  We chatted and drank till she kicked us out to the lobby when it was close time.  I also gave a scathing review of Omni too.  Not impressed with this place period
author: Chris J.

description: Worth every cent on the bill. You don't need to be a high roller to enjoy the Best Steak in town but it helps. My friend and I enjoy a great lunch together every now and then and this was the right choice. From the time we arrived for our reservation at 1pm, we were warmly received  and shown to a table right off the entrance. The room was a gathering of nicely dressed people enjoying the ambiance of conversation and the view of the tall windows that viewed the street. The room had a magnificent decor and the waiters were busy serving the last of the lunch patrons. Since this was our first time there, we decided to share a Cote De Boeuf. Excellent to say the least. The first bite was so perfect that it melted in my mouth from perfection. We shared a prime rib tartare and that was a wonderous venture in itself. To clean my pallet I enjoyed a nice glass of Prosecco. My friend had a IPA Lagunitsa. For me it was to savor every bite with a side of sliced carrots that had a glaze of cinnamon and smashed potatoes that smelled of garlic and butter. Though out our meal we were well treated and serviced by the waiter named Thai, a gentlemen indeed, very helpful about the information about the meat and very attentive, a job well done. My friend and I conversed for about 2 hrs and enjoyed every minute of it over a wonderful meal and great service by Thai. We'll have to work a couple of extra hours to be able to come back but it will be soooooo worth it. . .
author: John94521 H.

description:
Went to Bob's for the third or fourth time, and I have to say that it's really good.  Split a ribeye and a veal chop with a friend, both were fantastic.  Nice strong martinis, nice big onion rings, not-so-nice high prices, but hey, you don't come to a steakhouse expecting a dollar menu.

Skip the creamed spinach, by the way; it's woefully over-cloved.
author: Marco C.

description:
I got the filet rare and my dad got the filet medium rare. Both were cooked perfectly! My steak was the best steak I have ever had (coming from Oklahoma I've had quite a few). The smashed potatoes were delicious as well. 
The wait staff was OUTSTANDING!! Very friendly and tentative. My water glass was never below half full. They were able to answer every question/request we had. I am VERY impressed with this restaurant.
author: Melanie B.

description: Bought the OpenTable deal $50 for $25 coupon. Decent steakhouse. Loved the complimentary pickled peppers and cucumbers and the candied carrot. Steak was ok. Had the 12oz rib-eye, med-rare. Funny, I just realized that my favorite items at a STEAKHOUSE were its vegetables!!! I-R-O-N-Y!
author: Stephen Y.

description: Server was friendly but really lost. Would expect better for a place like this. She didn't know the specials. She messed up our orders.  Had to ask twice several times. Didn't get our bread until halfway through our meal. Food was good though.
author: Glen H.

description: Loved the complimentary roasted peppers & dill pickles at every table. The famous glazed carrot?  Disappointing.  My ribeye was tender and flavorful, but what isn't when bathed in butter.  Crispy skillet potatoes drenched in brown gravy were sensational. I recommend the Hawk Crest cab.  Could have killed a whole bottle.
author: Carol S.

description:
Got room service while staying at Omni and steak came out a little overdone (I think its from being cooked and kept under a steel tin until it made it to our room)...but being a prime cut the extra marbling kept the ribeye super moist and extremely flavorful
The seasoning was very good, reminded me of salt, pepper, light sugar and maybe cinnamon?  
Potatoes were okay.  

Steve out
author: Steve M.

description:
Really disappointed... went to the bar for a simple hamburger and the kitchen screwed up Medium Rare... twice!  Bar tender saw the first initially and was very proactive (huge points...)  When the kitchen tried again, she didn't even had to ask... went straight to the manager and comp'ed the hamburger.

Service was great... kitchen... not so much...
author: Rheinhart Saxon V.

description: Excellent service, location, food and portion! I love the pickles which is placed on every table. It compliments with the nicely made cocktail.
author: Kay D.

description: The restaurant was a bit noisy. The steaks were nice.  Staff helpful.  The grotesquely giant sugar coated candied carrot in the middle of everyone's plate were inedible. So were the pan seared potatoes and onions, which had a ducky sweet gravy on top. My recommendation: get the steak and the french fries.  And nothing else !!!
author: Larry S.

description: The Kansas City Strip I had here was cooked and seasoned perfectly.  It had a nice char on the outside, but was good and medium rare on the inside.  The service was also fantastic.  The sides to the meal were just okay, but most people go to a steak house for the meat, not the sides.  My salad was decent, but not out of this world.  Prices are a little on the high side, even for the FiDi, but the steak was definitely worth it.  Ambiance is very nice.
author: Scott E.

description: If I had known sooner about a restaurant which offers pickles pickled in-house on the table, I would've came here much sooner! First, I must say, the pickles were amazing!!! They complimented the delicious bread oh-so-well! We came here on a whim one random night per recommendation of some friends. We were clearly the youngest and most under dressed people there, but it didn't make the waiters or host treat us any different which I must stress is a GREAT aspect of a restaurant!!! I can't even tell you how much that's appreciated. I hate feeling doubted due to my younger age and relaxed appearance. Anyways, my man ordered the giant porterhouse with smashed potatoes and myself the 9 oz filet with baked potato... You know a steak is good when you have zero desire for any added steak sauces! We finished every last bite. I also purchased a bottle of the Gundlach Bundschu 2010 Cabernet for $45 which was absolutely delicious!! My inner wine snob loves cab that is aged in French oak specifically, and this is one of them! The vineyard retails the bottle for $40, so $45 does not feel like you're being robbed by inflation like many other restaurants do... This was a very pleasant surprise! I would recommend purchasing this bottle time and time again if you're ordering any red meat for sure and love a delightful cab at a reasonable price!!! Corkage is $25, take that for what it is. After our entrees, we ordered creme brûlée for dessert. More thumbs up here! The only downside was that the parking garage closed at 9 when the restaurant was closing at 10, but it worked out well for us anyways. My other half and I will certainly be back!
author: Shelby P.

description:
Stepping into this joint takes me back to a scene from Mad Men.  Instantly you recognize that the room is filled predominantly with men in business suits.  I'm sure a lot of them have expense accounts and plenty frequent there as if it was our local McDs from high school.  In any case, onto the Cote de Beauf!

My that is one tender fine piece of meat stuck to the bone.  That is, the Cote de Beauf.  A few friends of mine decided to go at it on a steak streak for some time and finally came across Bob's, one that I've heard plenty about but never made the effort to go.  But I'm glad I did and tasting that first bite of the savory, meaty, goodness that I've had the privilege of cutting up and devouring was in its own a well rounded moment of indulgence, in its purest forms.  

Not only is this meat perhaps aged, it's got the marbling and with the instruction for a Rare Temperature, they did just that and gave me a bloody great steak.  Not to forget, that big ass carrot that sticks out like an eye sore reminds you who's boss, and that's Bob.  Bob's carrot is perhaps cooked in duck fat as it comes out glistening and separates between the steak and the skillet potatoes which were practically homemade potato chips smothered in pepper gravy.  Delicious all across the board. 

I also made the unfortunately mistake of eating a bit too much bread, which was nicely warmed and almost similar to the HOPR bread, but the kicker is the pickles in the jar they provided.  I love slightly salted pickles, and they had it.  So those two items were probably a foolish move, but luckily I did finish my entire meal with no regrets.  

Now.....when to go back.......
author: Vincent K.

description: My friend took me here and treated me for dinner, in the heart of finical district, price are high but was expected, overall food and serves were good.
author: Eddy T.

description:
I used to work across the street from Bob's and my co-worker and I would stop in at least twice a month.  In addition to the delicious dungeness cobb salad, we absolutely loved the sourdough round that they served to each table.  Unfortunately, though, near the end of my employment across the street from Bob's, they started using a different baker and the bread just wasn't the same...

Anyway, I hadn't been to Bob's in years and my bf had been wanting to go because his mother once told him that the chicken-fried ribeye was delicious so I decided to treat him to Bob's around the holidays.  To our dismay we learned that both the dungeness cobb salad that I loved so much and the chicken-fried ribeye that his mother recommended were only served at lunch.  To my pleasure, however, the sourdough round of yumminess was BACK!  Thankfully Bob's returned to the baker they had previously used!

Even though the items that we planned to order weren't offered at dinner, we were able to find plenty of things on the menu that appealed to us.  Ultimately, we decided to share the Prime "Bone In" Kansas City Strip and the skillet fried potatoes with sauteed onions and peppercorn gravy.  Because we were sharing the steak, our server brought it out to us on two separate plates with separate servings of both the potatoes and the glazed carrot they serve with every entree.  The steak was quite delicious, but the potatoes were a little too crunchy for my taste, and I really didn't care for the glazed carrot.  My bf, however, ate both of our carrots - I guess it's one of those things that you either love or you hate.

For dessert I was planning on ordering the creme brulee but our server convinced us to try the banana nut rum bread pudding.  Admittedly I'm not really a fan of bread pudding but our server raved about it so much I decided to give it another try.  I thought that the bread pudding was just ok and our server offered to deduct it from our bill since we would've ordered the creme brulee if it wasn't for his suggestion.  However, I told him that it wasn't necessary - the bread pudding wasn't horrible (we did manage to finish it all) I guess bread pudding just isn't my thing.

All in all we had a great meal and a great time.  Our server was very friendly and helped to set the tone for a great night out.  We will definitely return - but next time we're going during lunch!
author: Laura L.

description:
Super good steaks, some of the best in San Francisco...

Never packed, you can walk in and get a seat....

Never know what celebrity you may see....
author: Stephen H.

description:
Took the folks out to Bob's for some nice steak.  Choose this place based on my brother's recommendation.  Should of known better but that's another story.  Bob's is located in the Omni hotel in the heart of san francisco's financial district.  Parking is hell in this area especially on weekdays, but lucky the folks lived close enough where we walked to dinner.

I think the Omni was renovated recently but everything in the restaurant just seemed... old.  From the curtains, to the table cloth, to the carpet, everything looks dated.  The color of everything seems faded as if one too many summers under the sun.  There basically is no good view as the restaurant is at street level and right beyond the wall of tall windows is the bustling after work street traffic.  Maybe some people do enjoy that kind of view, I don't know.

It is common for hotel restaurants to be overly priced but generally the quality of the food is pleasing enough to pardon the pain in the wallet.  This place lives up to being over priced, but fail miserably to deliver even a mediocre steak.  The only steak they got right was the one cooked rare.  

Seems like it's signature for this place to add a big fat carrot to each steak plate.  So imagine this, a big pot filled with carrots cooking in water until someone orders a steak.  That's how tasteless and overcook the carrot was.  Maybe a little bit classier veggie side?

They do have very courteous servers.  Though to be call a steak place in the heart of san francisco, it will take a lot more than just pleasant service to overcome the ugly decor and poor quality steak.  

Don't come here.
author: Vito L.

description: I really enjoyed my meal at Bob's. The food was amazing and excellent service to match. It was cool to see an edible centerpiece but the pickles were a bit too dilly for me. Can't really knock the restaurant for that; it was definitely a welcomed addition to our table. Was surprised at the quality of bread placed on the table. Everything from appetizer to dessert was phenomenal. Not sure why people thought the service was cold; I didn't notice an ounce of unfriendliness here.
author: Tommy C.

description:
I really like their bone-in rib eye and really want to give them a 4-star.  However, I lowered them 2-stars just because of what one of their associates (Adam) said to me and my date when we walked in.  

Initially my date and I wanted to just go to Alfred's Steakhouse just because we were in need for a good steak.  Though Alfred's was closed for some reason so we decided to go to Bob's.  Found street parking and walked in the front door to be greeted by three hosts at the front desk/podium.  Immediately looking to my right where the dining area was...it was pretty empty except for about 3 tables occupied.  We then proceeded to ask for a table for two.  Adam then immediately asked "have you been here before...would you like to look at the menu first?"  I was totally shocked and dumbfounded when I heard this and was speechless....I just said "no"....keep in mind that this was a impromptu dinner just because we wanted a steak...dressed down to Giants gear, baseball cap, and baggy jeans with sneakers.  He walked us to one of their many tables that was vacant.  Then I thought to myself...what did he just ask me??  He asked me to look at the menu first before he seated us??  What does that mean??  Wow!!  I then realized that this guy Adam didn't believe we could of paid for this meal due to the way we were dressed??  WTF?!?  I got over it and just kept my mouth shut as I didn't want to cause a scene...but I'll be damned if I don't let my fellow Yelpers know about this experience!!

Bob's - Please hire non-discriminatory people...or just plain training on this issue might help.  I'll just take it that that guy Adam is from the mid-west somewhere and haven't ever seen any Asians wearing sports attire afford a $50 steak...
author: Patrick C.

description: This review is for brunch. Hubby had the Crab Eggs Benedict $19 and I had the traditional $19. Service was great. ? My hubby did have a huge chunk of shell on his first bite, but the taste made up for it. It came with with some scalloped hash and an awesome brownie. The brownie was the gold nugget for me. It had fudge inside! Anyway, would I go back? Yes if it's on the way... but would not be one of those... hey let's go to Bob's next week...
author: Kathleen G.

description: The pickles at the beginning were different.  Nothing special.  I'd rather Ruth's Chris or Morton's.
author: Ken C.

description:
For a place like this, 5 stars should be their standard..

The President of my parent company was visiting from Japan and he invited everyone to a very nice dinner outing here at Bob's. This place had to be one of the most elegant and beautiful restaurants I've ever entered. I just saw $$$ signs everywhere I look around the restaurant. They had one of the most comfortable leather seats, it was like sitting on a cloud, soft and fluffy. 

For the first course, I ordered their lobster bisque. That had an excellent flavor and had little chunky pieces of lobster. Some of my colleagues who had the soup said that it was a bit salty, I thought it was just right.

For my main course, I had their 28 oz Porter House Steak. It's a bone-in steak with a tenderloin and top loin (New York Steak) served with house fried potatoes with gravy sauce and carrot. I ordered mine MR but it came out MW. Since I was at a company dinner, I didn't want to send it back until I told my colleague that it was overcooked. Once the server came to attention, he realize that it was and he took it back to the kitchen. This is really nice of them to do that because they want to Make It Right for their customers. 

The reason why I didn't want them to make a new steak because they will rush it and you don't want rush a porter house steak. Since its bone-in, it takes much longer to cook to perfection. Additionally, everyone else would be finished by the time I get my steak. The server said 10 minutes but it took more like 20 minutes.. 

Once my steak came to my table, everyone was pretty much finished. I sliced the middle part of the steak and it was really rare. Luckily, I can eat a steak that is seared. The server came to attention and asked me if I want it cooked a little more. I really appreciate the servers concern but I just accepted the way it was. 

I like eating my steaks R but the porter house is a think cut steak and beautifully marbles with fat, you want it cooked MR. The quality of the steak is top notch. It wasn't chewy at all and had a texture of Maguro (Tuna Sashimi) very very tender. I couldn't finish the steak since so much time has elapsed.

I would have rated Bob's 3 stars but the service and effort deserves an extra star. For the price you pay, you will get phenomenal service eating here.
author: Hideo M.

description:
Steaks were not bad. I liked my bone-in ribeye steak although it wasn't anything exceptional or memorable. I appreciate that the steaks come with sides of potatoes and a glazed carrot (unlike Ruth Chris's which offers only a piece of meat). 

Service was ok but our server was kinda weird. The guy was kinda quirky and trying too hard, I think, which in turn led to a few awkward moments for us at the table.
author: Al B.

description:
We arrived a few minutes before our reservation and were seated promptly. Service was impeccable, maybe due in part to the fact that we were one of four tables in the restaurant. Still, our glasses were always full and we were well taken care of.

The food was delicious, but be careful if you have a small table (i.e. two people). The portions are very large. My wife ordered a few vegetables and I ordered a filet with skillet fried potatoes. We literally left 2/3 of the food to be thrown away... Such a waste too because it was all very good. 

My filet was cooked perfectly and seasoned very well. It had a great flavor - definitely one of the better steaks I've had. The potatoes were great too... crunchy but covered in sautéed mushrooms and sauce. The carrot was much larger than I expected. I also tried my wife's broccoli and asparagus and both were cooked very well. 

The beverages were made quickly and very well, and our waiter kept our water filled and made sure we were okay several times. I also ordered one of the less expensive glasses of wine to have with my steak and it was very good.

My only caveat is that I was too tired from the flight to SF to really be able to relax and enjoy a few drinks and the meal. We ate and promptly retreated to our room for some much needed R&R. 

If there was anything else I could complain about, it's the price. I'm not wealthy nor were we dining on a company card... and $150 for dinner for two is a little high for a hotel steakhouse. I would have preferred to have paid $100 and gotten half the food (that we threw away anyway). If $75-100 a person doesn't even make you flinch, you'll likely find Bob's to be a 4-star restaurant.
author: Brandon E.

description: We were looking for an upscale Steak House and we were prepared for the cost.  Bob's is pretty pricey, as the saying goes, you pay for what you get.  The service and food were extremely good. The restaurant and bar were very busy for a Monday night.  They set us up with excellent boxes as a dogie bag which made my dinner the next day.  If you love steak dinners, I highly recommend this place.
author: Tom D.

description: Consistently the best steak in SF. Wedge, 9oz filet, red wine. You can't possibly go wrong with Bob's.
author: Dan L.

description: Ate here for breakfast. The waiter was super helpful and candid about what he felt was good. I went with the steak & eggs. The steak was super silky w/a crunchy sear on the outside. A total surprise. The eggs were cooked as requested and the potatoes were nicely seasoned and thinly sliced. The toast was on the burnt side and my partner got the omelette. He liked his meal as well but it wasn't a 'knock ur socks off' kind of breakfast. We will try this place for dinner.
author: Rae A.

description:
I'm from Texas and have been to the original Bob's in Dallas a number of times.  One of the things that I have struggled with since moving to the Bay area is finding what I would consider to be a good steak.  I've been to Alexander's which is good...but any steak that needs a sauce to cover it up is questionable in my mind.  Morton's and Ruth's Chris are consistently good, but very "chainy" feeling.  With the exception of Espetus which I don't consider to be a traditional steak place but a Brazilian churascaria and maybe some of the prime rib joints (Broadway Prime in Burlingame, House of Prime Rib in SF as examples), everything else in the Bay seems to be too overpriced for what you get or lean from being "grass fed" which to me results in little flavor.

I had the bone-in NY Strip with baked potato and a classic wedge salad.  The steak was thick, incredibly flavored, well marbled, and perfectly cooked.  The baked potato was unremarkable (not a ton you can do with a baked potato...let's be honest).  The salad was exactly what I was hoping for...a good chunk of iceberg lettuce loaded with blue cheese dressing, chopped crispy bacon, and diced tomatoes...simple, yet delicious.

If you haven't been to Bob's, I would highly recommend it.  All steaks come with their trademark huge, phallic cooked carrot which I generally ignore because I don't like cooked carrots.  Ask them for their pickle jar (which is kind of funny for a nice steak place to bring to your table as an appetizer).
author: Steve L.

description: Best steak I ever had!  Sure it's pricey but the service is top notch and the steaks were fantastic.  The wine list was very nice and not unreasonable considering the price of the beef.
author: Jeff G.

description:
This review is for Breakfast only 

Bob's Steak & Chop House just hosted my business breakfast meeting & we had a blast 

Swam to work today (torrential rain!) and was nicely greeted by the warm inviting lobby to wait on my coworkers 

Immediately as we are seated, comes the hot, fresh, coffee! Nice & super strong & the perfect remedy to a cold clammy morning 

All 3 of us opted for the French Toast 

HUGE slices of Brioche bread w/ fresh fruit, fruit compote, powdered sugar & pure maple syrup 

The edges of the bread were nice & custardy but the middle was a bit dry - hence the 4 stars. But we still somehow found a way to finish off our plates 

Would totally come back for the French Toast & will happily bump up my rating upon the discovery of fully-custarded bread....please soak a bit longer! 

PS   Was told by 1 coworker that this place makes a "rockin" homemade Key Lime Pie & he's found none better..... & I trust his food taste....you should too
author: Adrienne G.

description: Likes: seared salmon salad.  The salmon was deliciously seasoned and cooked with a soft interior and perfect outer crisp.  The dish was medium sized and came with radish, daikon, spinach, and mushrooms.  Our server was very friendly.  I only wish I had more room to eat their on-the-house bread.
author: Karen M.

description:
My sister and I thought it would be fun to wander away from our hotel and get lost in the financial district in search of a place to eat.. 

After walking past countless crackheads in the blistering cold; we came across Bob's Steak and Chop House. 

I originally wanted to sit on the bar side for a big juicy burger but settled for the upscale dining room instead. I was very pleased with my decision. 

We were famished so we loaded up on bread and then our food came....


SOOOOO MUCH FOOD! 

I ordered the Pork Chops (Two eight ounce I believe)

My sister got the One Half Roasted Duck (HOLY COW IT WAS BIG) 

The food was SUPERB

SERVICE WAS A+++++

Price wasn't too bad I believe I had a glass of oj with my meal and left like 70 including tip? 

Very nice I'll be back next time I'm in town
author: Ashley B.

description: Good restaurant for lunch, the tri-trip sandwich is very good. I was there for dinner and their steak was not worth the money.When my ($12) Costco Rib-Eye is more tender, juicier and tastier than theirs at $45, I have to drop a Star off the Rating. My daughter's Filet Mignon was not cooked right; I'm sorry but a [true and pricey] steakhouse has to get that part right the first time; but they did bring fresh/hot fries with her steak
author: A. C.

description: Wagyu rib eye was amazing!  But also $100.  This can be split among 2 or shared family style.  Service was amazing.  Onion rings need a different crispier batter (on the bready side).  Scampi lacked flavor but shrimp were large fresh n good.  The fried potato side (imagine scalloped potatoes with no cheese and fried not baked) was soooo good.  Drinks were all excellent.  A nice quiet place to dine and talk.  Was perfect for a celebration dinner :)
author: Camille L.

description: filet mignon was cooked as requested.  I did not like the carrots that came with it, service was excellent.
author: Jason L.

description: Extraordinarily disappointed with being served 16 oz filet steaks that were so full of fat, and tendons that over half the steak ended up in the trash. And not just once, but the last 2 times we dined here. So expensive for low quality steak.
author: K. N.

description:
I came here for a client dinner as an invited guest. We had asked for a quiet place and they sat us in a semi-public nice little room with a booth.

The service was decent, I felt that the waiter had intentionally gauged our needs, and since we were involved in business conversation he tried not to bother us often.

I ordered a wedge salad, and the bone-in NY strip medium rare, and we ordered two bottles of wine. Everything was fantastic. My steak was cooked perfectly and melted in my mouth. One of the best steaks I have ever had quite frankly. 

This place is very nice, but still manages to maintain a somewhat casual fee, where you don't feel stuffy or uncomfortable, but can still enjoy fine dining. I would definitely recommend this place.
author: Neal F.

description:
Hands down, the best garlic mashed potatoes I've ever eaten at a beef dispensary.

Also, hands down, the long, phallic shaped, braised carrot, is the weirdest thing to serve in a beef dispensary.

They got the rib-eye perfectly medium-rare at the time it was served, but ended up being much closer to medium since it took me a while to stuff the last morsel into my stomach. 

What I should have gotten, were the onion rings. They looked  beyond anything I've ever had or seen. When they came out to another patron's table, I had to nail my hands down to prevent myself from ordering a plate that would have sent me into an obese state of satisfaction.

Waiters come above average with knowledge and the I-will-fold-your-napkin-while-you-pee kind of service.

Great place to have a steak. I think this place deserves to be on anyone's bucket list for beef eats, and I'm almost thinking it's often overlooked. Don't make the same mistake!
author: Alfred Y.
