i have to say, my rib eye was super juicy (photos uploaded), and i can't tell you how much i loved every bit of it ... i also loved his filet mignon... both were fantastically tender and super yummy ... what pretty much was upsetting was their service, but it wasn't such a big deal ... we started off with their spinach salad which was pretty tasty for $10, a bit on the sweeter end, tossed w/honey poppy dressing topped with mushrooms and bacon... and  their soup of the day was carrot ginger, which was quite thick, and a good size (photo uploaded), well enough to be shared between 2 ppl ... 

it wouldn't be my favorite steak place, but it was considerably quite tasty ... thanks to Mr. Lin & Mr. Chu ... :) (both parties for suggesting and in taking me) ehehhe. you guys rock!

i hope you like my photo capability, its because i have an iphone now. lol
author: Jennifer S.

description:
The steak I had here was by far the best I have had in a very long time!!  I had the filet mignon which was cooked perfectly and was so juicy and tender!!!  Yum!!  My husbands new york steak was equally juicy!  You get your choice of potato and along with it comes a big apple glazed carrot, and I mean this is a huge carrot folks!!

My husband had a couple long islands and said they were pretty strong and got him to where he wanted to be! :)

Our bill with drinks, entrees, and dessert came out to about $120 which was not too bad!!

It is a small restaurant but has enough room to a have a private conversation.  The waiters were very good at refilling glasses and always coming over to make sure everything was fine!!
author: Alicia C.

description:
I ate here last night because the people I was with (including myself) wanted to eat some good steak.  We searched a different places but the 2 we wanted to go to was closed for renovation (argh!)  and the 2 others we went to closed between 8 and 9.  So we chose this place because of the convenience of the time it closed. What steak places are open until 1030?? On a Sunday? Well this one is!

About the food:
Fries were good, creamed corn was delicious, the filet mignon was good as well (not the best but it was good, I finished it!) The smashed potatoes was the best and so was the glazed carrot (yuuuum).  The prices were sky high for a normal tasting steak which is why I gave it 4 stars.
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
We all meet in the bar about 8:15ish.  There are 7 of us for dinner followed by some kind of entertainment - as of yet unknown.  There is a lot of talk about economics and especially the housing bubble and its bursting - we fancy ourselves experts and we take turns trying to outdo one another's analysis of the situation.  The drinks are well poured so we keep drinking.  After a couple drinks, someone always picks up the tab - at some point after a number of these evenings, you begin to get the sense that you have not gotten the drinks for some time and this time is probably your turn, when you get that feeling you buy.  Of course this is not policed in any way.

Around 9 -9:30 we sit down at our table.  People around us get looks of concern on their faces when they see us walking towards them - this, obviously to them, can come to no good.  It doesn't help that one in our party is audibly slurring his words.  As he sits we give him some bread before he is allowed to order any more drinks.

We have another round of cocktails as we wait for our order.  All but one of us gets some form of red meat - the lone man out gets salmon.  WHAT?!?!?!?  He is the brunt of every joke for the rest of the evening.  His explanation, he had steak the night before???  Moron.  He will never do that again - the peer pressure is so great.  You may think I am kidding, I am not!

Couple guys get salads (The Caesar looks good, but the beefsteak tomato with Red Onion is the winner), couple others get soup and the table shares a couple orders of the Shrimp Platter, Mushrooms, Onion Rings and Calamari.  Accepting the mushrooms, everything is very good.

Seeing empty glasses, our waiter asks if anyone would like another cocktail (its probably 10:15 already).  There are a couple cocktail orders and the rest of us order wine which lasts through dinner.

When everyone's food arrives the table gets quiet for a bit as it takes in the Baked potatoes, the Creamed Spinach, the broccoli and the Asparagus...  which are all good.  My favorites are the bakers (when I am in the carb mood) and the asparagus which is always excellent...  Ahhh, and the steaks (and of course the silly plate of salmon) - someone let him know what guys night out is all about.  The slight scent of pepper and freshly cooked steaks permeates the air around the table, mixing with the scents from around the large room to form a delicious redolence.  As the moment passes, conversation picks up again and we all start to eat, hardly aware of the pause at all.

Everything is great.  The wine pours and the Zinfandel mixes well with the filet as to nearly bring a tear to my eye... nearly - I am with the guys and this salmon eating fool is the heel this night and I am certainly not taking that away from him. 

After dinner, of course, cognac for some, coffee for others.  Everyone is visibly relaxed and happy!

Bob's is very, very good.  But Harris' is my 5*, so I have to give Bob's a 4 - it is really a 4.9, but rounding would not be fair to Harris'.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
I've been going to Bob's for seven years or so now.  It used to be that Bob's was the quintissential American steakhouse.  Unfortunately, since the franchise owner sold to the Omni hotel, the quality and consistency has slipped.  But my hope is that Bob's will regain it's rightful place as truly one of the best steakhouses in the country.  

First, the poor.  Bob's has never had the best sides.  The creamed spinach, onion rings and other sides are very good.  But not the greatest by any stretch.  But who cares.  I don't.  I go there for the steak.

If you are a ribeye fan, and true steak eaters should be because filet's are for wussies, then the bone-in "Cote de Boeuf" ribeye is the only way to go.  The meat is USDA Prime and is impeccably marbled with delicious fattiness that only my heart attack  jacket (my fat gut) can truly love.  They use a combination of wet and dry aging which I truly prefer.  The steaks are broiled, which in my opinion, is the only way to lock in flavor.  When done right, the treat is a buttery melt in your mouth experience that will ruin your sex life for the night.  Trust me, I tried and may have done permanent damage to my heart.  And I even skipped desert that night.  But it's worth it.  

Speaking of deserts, I am preferential to the chocolate brownie, which, as all their deserts, serves about 5 people.  The wine list is outstanding and the by the glass wine is decent.  

I reccomend Bob's on a weeknight as that's when i have found the most consistency.  When they are on, there is no steakhouse in this town that can touch it.
author: Craig B.

description: I've been here several times and each time I think I should write a review. But since I've ordered the same thing every time I was waiting until I tried something else. After at least five visits that hasn't happened. So based on my limited sampling I would recommend this restaurant. The chopped salad followed by the New York Steak and baked potato.  That is my staple meal.  I would advise telling them you don't want the candied carrot that comes with it. Unless of course you like candied carrots. Even then tell them to put it on a separate plate.  Its just a large carrot and they put it right next to the steak. So then that part of your New York taste like a candied carrot. The beef is too good to be touched by the carrot.
author: Cindy B.

description:
First off, it was Christmas, and had family coming into to town from the provinces and they wanted to eat out "at someplace normal." So after calling 30 places that were closed on Christmas (of which I approve) we had to settle on this place. A little expensive, thought I, but at least it will be nice.
Oh, so very wrong. Like Katie and Tom. Like Angelina and Billy Bob. Like Liza and, and, well, anybody. 

Horrible management, slowwwwwwww service, when there was some, ands quite frankly, the steak wasn't all that. At $30-55, the steaks should be spectacular. And they were not. And what the fuck is up with that massive phallic carrot nuzzling up on my meat? That thing would shake John Holmes' confidence.
author: Big S.

description:
The crabcake was superb!!! the mashed potatoes great.  I don't understand the big carrot in the middle of the plate.  It's okay, but nothing special.  The steak is one of the best in San Francisco!  One of my favorites is the rib-eye.  

Decor is that of any steakhouse, deep red and dark wood.  There's also a TV to watch whatever game is on.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
bad bread, insane prices. Their basic steak is $53. um...

I live here, why did I try this place? Shame on me, really shame on me

$15 for a martini? And a LARGE carrot? What is that?!

 I want the last two hours of my life back.

Go to Houston's (a chain!) and you'll still come out better. 

The steak was small even for a 9oz.

baaaad
author: Stephen S.

description:
I'm assuming that most people come here for lunch on an expense account, as did I, but still somehow I didn't really find this place that appealing or delicious.  To begin with, I felt like I had stepped back in to the early '90s where business was still an old boys' club.  There were several tables full of men in their black suit and ties.  I guess there's not much the restaurant can do about their clientele, but it definitely made me as a woman feel uncomfortable.

Then the food was also not amazing.  Maybe this is because I'm a vegetarian and was eating at a steakhouse, but in SF, any restaurant needs to have one good veggie dish that's not just a sandwich.  Oh wait, that's what it was.  I had the potato leek soup as well, which wasn't bad.  But seriously, they just had a roasted veggie sandwich with some sprouts on top for $15?!
author: Olivia T.

description:
by far my measuring stick for all steak houses, been here 3 times everytime gets better, like most post you cannot deny the power of the "Cote De Beouf" med-rare or rare dont matter u can cut it with a spoon thats how tender this beef is.. all other steak houses fail in comparison that is in the city of course haha.. this is not a cheap steak but man wut u pay for in quality is priceless haha

price $$$$ for what you pay you get the best steak
food ***** you can cut your steak with a spoon literally
customer service ***** never had to ask for a refill, always on top of there game 
ambiance **** dark, roomy, classic white table covers, waiters come by after each session to clean your table with a small metal table cleaner
author: Clarence A.

description:
This is the BEST steakhouse in San Francisco.  I have been to all the others (yet to write reviews), and IMHO, nothing compares.

I grew up in Alabama on an angus beef cattle ranch and have always loved steak.  I have been to many steakhouses across the country and had (until this point) been somewhat dissapointed by steak in San Francisco.  this is no longer the case. My medium well steak was perfectely cooked  (which is no too common here) and the seasoning was right on cue.

I am giving this place 5 stars strictly for the steak.  The atmosphere is less than desirable.

I went here on my BDay and got the 28 ounce bone in Kansas City filet.
author: Spencer G.

description:
Three stars is a stretch here.  I thought this place was okay but not worth the money AT ALL.  I absolutely prefer Ruth's over this place.  I got the fillet mignon and we requested that our be cooked medium and they came out completely rare.  My sister's mashed potatos were better than my potato fried mess with mystery sauce on them.  The waitress was super apologetic and took them back and cooked them to our specifications but at the end of the day, was it the best cut of meat I have ever tasted??? NO.  
The tapas menu looked good though.  I wished I had gone that route.
author: Kirsten M.

description: I was not impressed. Calamari was not prepared fresh, I sent it back. Shrimp platter was acceptable , but not exceptional or remarkable. Caprese-style salad was a chopped mess - I was expecting an insalate caprese, not a thing that looked like it went through salad shooter. The bone in rib eye was not a premium cut in my estimation. It had stringy-strands and was not tender enough. Maybe it was a Wednesday night thing. My favorite part of the evening was the 08 ZD Cabernet.
author: Mick R.

description: I rather enjoyed the food here. Had the ribeye and although well flavored, it wasn't overly fatty. Service was good and espresso was decent as well. They have a decent bar if you're waiting (we weren't but I met somebody there to do an interview) and the snack mix is better than most. Would go there again.
author: Mark S.

description:
if i was staying at a business trip at the omni and wanted a beer and a burger, i would definitely go to the bar at bob's and watch the game

for any special occasion or serious steak dinner, i would recommend alexander's or harris'...and then there is always the house of prime rib
author: nick g.

description:
For me this is the place to be if you are looking for a nice and juicy steak. The portions are huge and I assure you will enjoy every single bite, even though is a bit pricey you wont regret it.

The waiters will guide you on your selection and don't hesitate to ask them if you want to get the best out of your plate. 

I wouldn't recommend this place for a date, it is more to go en enjoy a steak with your buddies and friends.

Wine menu is o.k but who cares, the meat is amazing!
author: Juan Camilo R.

description:
Pros:
1. Filet Mignon is very tasty.  I like my steak medium rare & they cooked it just how I like my meat.  

The so-so's:
1. With every steak order, comes with 2 sides.  I had th smashed potatoes & the asparagus.  I also tried my friend's glazed carrots & the buttered corn.  Overall, it was nothing memorable.  Straight-up: so-so.
2. I'm a sweet fanatic.  The brownie was absolutely GIGANTIC... to make up for the quality of flavor.  It was huge, but it didn't feel like it should belong to such a fine dining restaurant.  It seemed to be more suitable for a Mel's diner or something.  It's definitely not a Roy's hot chocolate souffle.  
 
The bad:
1. If I'm going to a fine dining restaurant with prices to match, I have high expectations for the food & service to back it up.  The high price & cleanliness is there.  Besides the steak, where did all the flavor run away to?  

This place is a true so-so.  Definitely wouldn't come here for a date or anything fancy-schmancy.
author: Sheryl S.

description:
My motto is "I'm a million dollars away from being a millionaire."  In reality, I guess it is more than that considering I owe the government enough to make Michael Corleone roll in his grave.  I went to this fine establishment with my wife and it made me feel like a million bucks without that funny money smell.  

This steakhouse makes Ruth's Chris, Morton's and Harris' look like they are still in the minor leagues.  I have absolutely no idea where Bob's gets their meat but they must coddle and feed these cows on a nipple because the meat was just that damn good!  My wife got the NY Steak and I got the Ribeye.  NY Steak came cooked medium.  She wanted it medium rare.  This place brought out a new piece of steak cooked PERFECTLY and even with a gesture of goodwill removed it from the bill.  These days that was above and beyond what anyone could possibly do.  My wife and I were floored.  Did I forget to mention that the Ribeye was fantastic?  

When the bread pudding came my wife's jaw dropped to the floor which really only happens when she sees Brad Pitt ala Fight Club.  So I salute Bob's on that feat!  

The waiter and the service was absolutely impeccable.  If there was a credit card that gave Bob's reward points, we would be jumping on it faster than PETA taking a shot at Michael Vick.   We will be absolutely returning when given the chance.  Hopefully upon our return I will be closer to that elusive goal of being a millionaire.  In the meantime Bob's will fill the bill and make me feel like one.
author: Bill P.

description:
Part of my job requires a fair amount of travel and and entertaining clients - at least once/twice per week.  Luckily I have the privilege of trying out a plethora of new restaurants...without paying for them myself.  Aside from "the scene" or the hype of a new hot-spot, I like to use one simple litmus test everywhere I go: "Would I go here with my family/friends and pay for it out of my own pocket?"  Let's face it, eating out can get really expensive and new restaurants featuring some "executive chef who once took a yoga class with Thomas Keller" are a dime-a-dozen and not always worth coming back to...let alone the $50-150+ per person, out the door.

Being a red-blooded American, I love my steak houses and Bob's Chop House was the last one on my list to try in San Francisco.  I was excited at first and it came highly recommended...more sophisticated than "Izzy's" (in the Marina) without the chain-store predictability of Morton's or Ruth's Chris (which are both good).  The service was prompt and polite.  Drinks were stiff and the wine list was extensive, if not a tad over-priced.  The first thing to hit the table was a big jar of pickles & red peppers.  Interesting touch but not appealing to me at all.  The bread arrived and looked pretty fresh but even the hulking steak knife couldn't cut through the little loaf.  Either provide sharper knives or cut the bread before you bring it out.  

Our table tried a variety of appetizers and sides including the $9 "Beefsteak Tomato Salad" which consists of two fat tomato slices and about a quarter of an onion sprinkled with Bleu Cheese.  Tasty...but not worth $9 each.  Steamed Broccoli was fresh and cooked just right.  Creamed Spinach (one of two "must have" sides at a killer steak house) was unoriginal and didn't stand out from the average mom/grandma/aunt recipe (think: "Marie Calendar's" quality).  Sauted Mushrooms were big and tender (perfectly cooked) with just the right amount of flavor in the "sauce" to not overpower the subtle flavor of the mushrooms.  

My entree plate came with a large carrot....which I promptly moved out of the way and something they called "Skillet Potatoes."  Every steak house has it's signature potato dish and this was it @ Bob's.  Imagine dumping out a bag of unsalted,  thick-cut potato chips from Trader Joe's on a plate followed by a ladle of sauted onions in a flavorless goo...ok...keep thinking about it...pretty gross, huh?  They were tough to chew and Impossible to cut with the large (but dull) steak knife (yes, I politely asked for a new knife - and it was of the same caliber).

And now, the main event, for 50% of Bob's grade, the MEAT....

I ordered the 20 oz. Prime Rib-Eye "Cote de Boeuf" ($41) at the recommendation of the waiter who insisted this was not just bigger than the 12 oz Rib-Eye (obviously) but I would notice the difference in flavor.  I prefer my slabs of meat medium rare...which is pink throughout and in my opinion, optimized for maximum tenderness and juiciness.  This was a "bone-in" cut with allot of fat and gristle.  So yeah, the dull steak knife came back to haunt me again.  Once I performed surgery on that bad-boy, I was left with about a 14 oz steak - which is really more than enough.  The meat had a decent flavor and was relatively tender (the dull knives not allowing for very small pieces) so it was OK.  Cooked to order, and seared just right on the outside.

But "OK" is the problem.  Bob's has a nice location in the Omni Hotel downtown ("A" for the after-work crowd), decent setting (B) and good service (B+) but it all goes straight downhill from there.  The bread/appetizers (B-), sides (C-) and Steak (C) were flat-out disappointing - especially for the value (D).  Our party of 4 had one round of drinks, one $45 generic bottle of Pinot, 2 apps, 2 sides and 4 steaks (from $30-41 ea) and we walked away for just under $400.  I don't consider myself a food-snob but I've "been there, done that" all over SF, NY, LA, etc - so I know what $400 should get a party of 4 and this was "insult to injury" on a grand scale.  

Take your clients and/or your Dad/Friends elsewhere...no matter who is paying.  Harris' is your best bet for an upscale steakhouse, Izzys for casual and I'm not touching the Morton's/Ruth's debate with a 10-foot pole.  Sorry guys, but it's time for "Extreme Makeover: Kitchen Edition."
author: Ari G.

description:
I know this place gets a mix of reviews, but my wife and I have visited here twice now and had great experiences both times. Service is excellent - an example: We are unsure of what type of wine to order with dinner. Our waiter made a recommendation but then he also went to the bar and brought back two glasses of his recommendation for us to try. And his recommendation was one of the less expensive bottles on the wine list - maybe they were pushing it that night, but we appreciated being able to taste first.

We went with their signature dishes - bone-in Kansas City strips. Both were prepared exactly as ordered and were awesome. So juicy and flavorful. Love the big carrot! How do they cook it to be so tender and sweet? The fried potatoes with peppercorn gravy is awesome. We split a dessert. Drinks beforehand were great as well. Yeah - it's expensive, but not disappointing. We try to visit at least 1-2 times each year. Big recommendation if you are a steak lover.
author: Mike R.

description: Good food. I like their steaks. Service is lacking though. I wouldn't come back here until they step up the service. The waittress we had was rude and never checked in on us; we had to ask the busboy for everything, including finding her to get our check.
author: Evelyn C.

description: An un-noteworthy burger experience.  The service was top-notch, but I really don't feel as though the price was earned by the middling quality of the food.  I'm sure there have to be better items on the menu, but I'm one of the rare people who tries to save a bit for the company while traveling, so a burger it was... sadly.
author: Ted P.

description:
I almost never eat beef. But last night I saw this place and immediately got a hankering for steak, so we ate there. their menu is long and chock full of meat meat meat. Steaks mostly but there are other items. 

The food was quite delicious. The asparagus salad was tasty. My steak was perfectly cooked and their smashed potatoes are really good. I didn't much care for the large carrot in the middle of my plate, but that really didn't matter. The wine was yummy and so was the meal. The next time I get a hankering for a steak I hope its still there!
author: Marz W.

description:
Great location, but it's like they're not even trying.  NY steak for lunch was 1/2 inch thin and chintzy, not what the NY cut should be.

Steakhouses are all about sourcing, and I don't get the sense their beef is top notch, esp when the other options are so much better (Bobo's, Harris', etc.) 

Take this with a grain of salt since I haven't had dinner there (just breakfast and lunch...but steaks at both.  Yep, had the steak and eggs.  My arteries are mad at me).

Great location, but too expensive by a long shot, esp for the steak quality.  Not "Bad" by any stretch, but a solid 2 stars.
author: Nate H.

description:
Took my brother here for his birthday. We were the second table sat that evening yet our entrees didn't arrive for about an hour after our salads. We asked the waiter and he made some lame excuse about waiting for everyone to finish their salads. 
Trust me, we had been finished for about 40 minutes.
Then the manager came by on his rounds and asked how everything was. Not good, friend. We need steak NOW! Or at least another martini. 

Nope. No excuses, no appetizers, just an incredibly weak apology. 
Granted, my dirty martini was good and when the food finally came it was delicious. I liked the whole glazed carrot but the sibs weren't fans. Oh, I forgot that although my brother ordered some kind of side on his potatoes, (mushroom gravy?) he didn't get it. Don't worry, the bill sure did. 
So we all agreed that the service was less than stellar, but the food made up for the overall experience. 
Then I got my bank statement. My sister and I had split the bill but somehow the whole thing was charged to my card. Plus tip, naturally. When I called the restaurant the manager left me a voice mail a few days later asking for my card number and the number of the card I wanted to split the bill with. I did not call back nor will I be going back.
author: deb C.

description:
I was in the San Francisco Bay area for a business trip a few weeks ago.  First, it was a flying nightmare with delays and layovers; however Bob's Steak and Chop House definitely saved the entire trip for me.  

After flying out at 7am from Charlotte, NC, dashing to a conference in Palo Alto, I was beat and ready for some good pampering by the end of the day.  

Both my co-worker and I were determined to salvage our trip by treating ourselves to a night on the town in San Franciscio.  After a quick nap (i'm an East Coast girl, so at 6pm it felt like 9pm), my co worker and I headed into the city around 8:30pm.  It was a Thursday, so there was a lot of activity and people out and about.  

None of us really knew the SF area- and were in search of food.  We parked in the shopping district which was a mistake as all the shops were closed by the time we arrived. 

We found a nice looking couple to ask for recommendations or directions for a nice place to eat.  Lucky for us, they were not tourists ,and were pretty enthusiastic about recommending places to eat.  

I know the the SF area has some GREAT foodie places to eat, so the girl asks us what type of food we are looking for, as there were many many places she and her bf could recommend.  So my coworker blurts out: "we want a nice steak dinner".  The girl perks up and says she knows a FABULOUS place; Bob's Steak and Chop House, the restaurant in the Omni Shore Hotel, conveniently located a mere two blocks away.  

Oh, and by the way, she works there as a server.  So thank you so much Audrey for the great recommendation, and my coworker and I did end up having a fabulous meal. :)  

By the time we sat down to eat, it was around 9pm, and hardly anyone else was dining at that time of night.  We practically had the entire restauarant to ourselves.  Our waitress; Shelly was gregarious and friendly.  

So it's 9PM and I was ready for a glass of wine.  I ask for a recommendation on which Shiraz is the best, and was surprised when the sommelier didn't choose the priciest one on the list.  Matchbook Shiraz is pretty darn good (i even hunted it down here in DC).  

Confession: this was the first time I actually had a fancy steak dinner in a fancy steak restaurant.  So I had to ask Shelly the difference between all the steaks ( iknow, shame on me).  however she was happy to give me a tutorial on steaks.  And I ended up getting the Porterhouse steak.  

When my food came out, all I can say was that it was beautiful.  My steak was cooked perfectly; I had asked for it be done medium rare, and it was melt in your mouth bliss.  The sides were a spiced glazed carrot and mashed potatoes; each equally well executed.  At one point I was unsure whether to finish my steak or potatoes- they were both that good.  I opted to finish the meat.  

By the time we both finished our meals, we were happy enough to just go back to the hotel.
author: Jaemie D.

description:
It's amazing to see the hot and cold responses on here...looks like Bob's needs to work on their management.

I'm a fan of Bob's - they are widely regarded as one of the best steakhouses in the country.  And the steaks ARE terrific.  And the phallic carrot always brings out a giggle - but it's a good freaking carrot.  I highly recommend the bone-in ribeye for those of you complaining about lack of flavor or juice.  There's no better choice of meat than a ribeye for the marbling...and the bone helps seal in the juices as well.  Bob's has the best ribeye I've ever had.

I think they need to do something about the atmosphere.  Bob's isn't the type of place that cares about something like that - they'd rather worry about the steaks.  But in San Francisco, it's a huge issue with foodies - especially Yelpers.  So while the plain decor is typical in it's home town (Dallas), you have to design a better interior for SF.  Cater to your audience, Bob...it's an obvious problem with these reviewers.

But...if I was in an alley eating his ribeye, I'd be happy...so I don't care about that stuff.  If you had a bad experience, call the manager - this is the type of place that takes that stuff seriously...I'm sure they'd invite you for another chance.
author: Nathan B.

description:
A buddy and I had the good fortune of flying into town on a business trip with an expense account.  The corporate American Express card was given a thorough workout here.  

Service was top-notch.  Great wine selection to start things off.  Steaks, lobsters, sides, all terrific.  When said and done, I am sure the meals were overpriced... and yeah, the quality wasn't the absolute best in the world... but it was a still a very good dinner made even better by the company's accountant having to figure out how to pay for it.
author: Jon W.

description:
I went here with a friend and had a good meal.  The onion rings are big but clumsily seasoned (is that Allspice?) and the wine was served warmer than it should have been (though, as I seem to be whining about this at every restaurant I visit, maybe I just like red colder than most).  I had the blue cheese something salad which was really good.

I had the 12oz Ribeye ($33) medium rare and it was cooked and seasoned very well.  I'm used to thicker steaks, but this was about 3/4 in. and it was great.  The potato chip things on the side were just OK.

Service was perfect.  This isn't my favorite place for a steak, but overall a good experience if you're going to pay a lot for steak.
author: Matt S.

description: I stopped by tonight for a quick dinner at the bar.  I was appalled at how long the bartender took to wait on me.  I watched him slowly make drinks, service the wait staff and completely ignore me.  He even took the time to cashout checks for patrons who have left, before servicing me, a new customer.  I  have been there several times in the past and have enjoyed my dinners there.  I walked out after waiting 10 minute for him to take my order.  I find that unbelievable for such an expensive restaurant.  I may never go back!
author: J P.

description:
Love love LOVE this restaurant. It is a great place to go after a hard day's work. The ambience is great and it's the ideal setting for relaxation with a glass of red.

Food: The BEST Filet Mignon in the city. The Cote de Beouf is very delicious. I also love the crab cakes. With your entree you get to choose either Skillet potatoes or Smashed Potatoes - I love the Skillet with extra Peppercorn Sauce. Really good Pinot - my drink of choice. Also, an extensive selection of liquor, which Eddie enjoys.

Price: A pricier restaurant, but I love the food and it is well worth the cost.

Ambience: Love it. Very relaxing. Dark wood, plush seating, and dim lighting. A great spot for a romantic dinner or a place to go to for the sole purpose of unwinding.

5 stars all the way. I really love this restaurant and never tire of the food.
author: MishEddie G.

description:
The place has an overall old school feel to it. The service was genuine and polite so nothing to complain about. I've ordered the new york strip steak as my friends ordered the ribeye and the cote de boeuf. Unfortunately for me, I did not enjoy the the ny strip at all as it tasted rather dry and chewy. My friends loved their meals, so I guess I should give this place another try with a different entree.

ps- I didn't dig the giant carrot at all. It made my experience even worse as I looked elsewhere away from my steak and all I could turn to was a giant piece of carrot on my plate...
author: Mike S.

description: Bob's chophouse inside the Omni Hotel San Francisco is another fine dining place if you are a meat eater.  I never order the fish there before.  They have a good hamburger too besides their choices of steaks, but it is only serve for lunch.  The portion is huge.  I always get sucker in by the large butter carrot.  You really cannot put anything else down after that.  It is more like the steak is for togo.  The price is fair for the ambience, service and food quality.  I go back when I am in that area.  I frankly think they should down size their portion.  This is not Texas.
author: Esme W.

description:
For some reason, I ended up eating here for LUNCH with co-workers and I swear I was going to burn a hole through my wallet while looking through the menu.  It looked like a cool place to bring the girlfriend for a night out but a Monday lunch?!

My work had only good things to say about Bob's before I set foot in the place and there was non-stop talk about the "Chicken Fried Rib-eye Plate", which is this gigantic piece of Chicken Fried Steak that pretty much covers the whole plate.  Since I am a lowly intern, I decided to go for their 1/2 lb burger instead of the "Fried Plate".  The burger was humungous.  You are given a choice of potatoes or salad but I just chose fries.  Everyone else got smashed potatoes and those looked VERY good.

I barely finished my monstous burger but I was eyeing everyone else's Chicken Fried Plate.  No one really finished theirs so I was able to finally try the heart attack that is Chicken Fried Plate... ... The company bathroom will probably never be the same again.
author: Chris C.

description: Although Peter Luger in NY remains my all time favorite steak house, Bob's has stepped up and now holds a special place near my heart or stomach.  The Fillet Mignon is phenomenal, the onion rings are out of this world.  I love the fact that when I bring my wife here, she never finishes her meal, so Buddha and I share the dogie bag.  I am very glad that my friend Norman Y recommended this place!
author: Javier O.

description: Should I get the $50+ rib eye steak on my employer's dime? No, that would be too uncool. The flatiron steak sandwich did the trick (pretty excellent, actually), with a side of skillet potatoes, which weren't anything special...but with that peppercorn gravy, very nice. So delicious.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Satisfying your in-laws is always a difficult task.  Satisfying your in-laws who will eat at only 5 restaurants and are not adverse to following a waiter into the kitchen when they are no satisfied is an even more difficult task.  The last time my in-laws came to S.F. my wife and I took them out to dinner.  We agonized over where to take them at first.  They like two kinds of food: Chinese and steak.  My wife was terrified to take them to a Chinese place because they might walk faster than Jane Kim can piss me off.  That left us with steak.  We immediately said, "Bobs".  Why?  Because it's damn good.  

Let's start with the pickles.  Pickles?  Yup pickles.  There is a jar of pickles on the table that Snooki was lose her poof over.  They're awesome.  Be careful not to eat too many.  My mothe-in-law ate two, and then brought some home. I should not spend so much time on pickles.  They're just evidence that everything at Bob's is great from start to finish.  Speaking of starters, the calamari is awesome.  Once again, don't eat too much or you'll ruin your dinner.  And dinner rocks.  Now, I don't eat steak, so my opinion may seem kinda meaningless.  However, I can comment on the fish.  I have said many times that steakhouses have the best fish.  Bob's may have the best steakhouse fish I have ever had.  So, my fellow sissies, if you love fish go to Bob's.  But I should give you a clue about what Bob's specializes in.  Steak.  My in-laws ate, and ate, and ate.  They did not look up.  They did not pause.  They did not say a word.  They focused on the task at hand.  This is the ulitmate compliment.  When my in laws eat everything in silence they are happy.  Go to Bob's and make yourself happy.
author: Chris I.

description:
My first experience with Bob's was at a Christmas dinner I had to plan VERY last minute.  They were not only able to accommodate us, but did so with grace and a smile.

The steaks are perfection but the burger is to die for!  The crab salad sandwich is decadent and divine.

If you can get  past the association with the hotel, you are in for a great meal.
author: Sarah T.

description:
There's just one word to describe Bob's Steak & Chop House: AMAZING! Now, amazing is a word that I do not throw around lightly. It's usually reserved for a select few things, such as hitting a 5-team NFL parlay in Vegas or Amy Adams' tits in The Fighter. But my friends, the food at Bob's is just truly that: amazing.

The boss & I checked out Bob's for our Christmas Eve dinner last night after bailing on the fam back in New York 'cause of the snow. We initially were supposed to spend a week in the Rotten Apple, but had to come home to SF as soon as Delta started cancelling flights on the East Coast. Alas, we had to cancel a reso at Quality Meats in Manhattan, which left me hankering for a big 'ol NY steak. We decided to try Bob's after seeing their ad in, of all places, US Airways magazine. They were mentioned in the same breath as David Burke's Primehouse in Chicago, so we figured we'd give it a shot.

And boy, are we glad we did! We ordered the Smoked Salmon app, another NY staple that I didn't get to indulge in, 6 huge cuts of perfectly smoked salmon served with hard-boiled eggs, onions and toast points. The salmon was great, but the real stars of the show were still to come. I had the 16 oz. filet mignon with the baked potato. The steak was absolutely fantastic, cooked to a perfect medium-rare with a beautiful crust on the outside while staying fork-tender in the middle. It was honestly the best steak I've had in SF, hands down. The baked potato is served with sides of sour cream, bacon, chives, and shredded cheddar, so you can customize the topping level to your liking (I, of course, went all-in). Wifey had the nightly special, which was a 6 oz. filet with a blue cheese crust accompanied by a 6 oz. of Pacific Red Snapper with pesto and blue cheese mashed potatoes. Her filet was cooked as perfectly as mine, with the blue cheese crust adding a deeper, smokier flavor. The ol' lady LOVED her filet, but the snapper took her breath away. She is a pesto freak, and the pesto at Bob's is better than top-notch. For you pesto lovers out there, Bob's makes the most intense, flavorful pesto you'll find anywhere, which leant just the right amount of taste to the light, flaky fish. We also ordered a side of creamed spinach, which was perfectly thick and rich and topped with an awesome cheese crust. Trust me, the spinach is an absolute must!

Of course, we split a banana-rum bread pudding for dessert. The banana flavor was omnipresent in the crumbly pudding, accented with caramelized bananas and golden raisins in a pool of banana-rum sauce. It was truly the perfect ending to a memorable meal. If you're looking for a real NY steakhouse experience, add Bob's to your list immediately!
author: Michael T.

description: Old reliable. Wedge and rib eye in under 30 minutes. Hard to beat if on the road or in a rush
author: Anthony N.

description:
So I was the with the BF, Shane P., and James R., celebrating James' bday . Went to the bar and started off with some J Sparkling Wine (J Vineyards is one of my FAVORITES right now!!!), then we were seated. Ok, service was good! Our guy was totally attentive and was rather entertaining without being overly showboaty or annoying! What WAS annoying was the table behind us that had a woman that I want to assume was drunk & was hackling like no one's business. It was SO funny that we could not help ourselves from laughing out loud either! That was actually funny!
As for the food, we started with Onion Rings & the Crab cake, literally A crab cake, however was VERY dense & good and the Onion Rings, keep in mind the onions must have been on steroids, they were HUGE & good actually! The entrees overall were ok, uneventful as well as the place. Nothing to write home about.
author: Rob L.

description:
Service:
1) We came ahead of the crowd to ensure what we hoped would be a quick service; it took more than 15 min for the appetizer to be served, and the same happened for the main course. The steak was tepid at best when served, clearly having waited for me in the kitchen. Might be understaffed for the lunch crowd.
2) When serving steaks by the oz, it would be nice to have the waiter prompt you whether you desire 8 or 12 oz, rather than him sticking a 12 oz and discovering this fact later on the bill. Not cool!

Food:
1) The New-York steak was poorly cut and tough.
2) The fillet was average and plain.
3) Carrots were way under cooked.
author: Christophe M.

description:
Maybe it was fate to discover this delicious cuisine.  Until last Sunday, I had no idea that most of the restaurants are closed in the financial district.  I guess, all except for one, Bob's Steak and Chophouse.

After a cosmopolitan martini, my house salad was delivered and it tasted homemade.. just perfect.  With dinner we ordered a bottle of wine, Pinot Grigio.  I love my wine and enjoyed this bottle.  My 9 oz. (there are 3 choices of size) medium rare steak was another perfect addition to my meal.  I ordered the baked potato.. but next time I'm gonna opt for the smashed, not mashed but smashed, potatoes.  I don't get the deal with the extremely large carrots served with each entree.. but it was tasty too with an apple cinnamon flavor.  

The service was perfect as well.  The server was always there when you needed him and all of the food was delivered in the right amount of time.  The service was so good in fact, that I couldn't recall how many glasses of wine I had, because he was the one keeping our glasses full.  

It was a quiet place for a Sunday, but I guess that whole area is just quiet on Sundays and I have no complaints with quiet in the city :)
author: Michelle N.

description:
With so many fine steakhouses in San Francisco to choose from, it's not clear why you'd go to Bob's. It's adequate, but expensive and not particularly great. Nice reasonably price wined list though, and the room is pleasant.

My bone-in rib eye was good, properly cooked if not hot. Potatoes were fine, salad was OK. But who the hell puts a carrot covered in corn syrup in the middle of a dinner plate? Yuck! The corn syrup flowed over to the potatoes and the steak, giving everything a cloying sweetness like a third grade school lunch.
author: Nelson M.

description: 1 star for pickles...This review is for the bar side of the restaurant at lunch. You have got to be kidding me! Strike Deuce and I could have had a better lunch at the Subway across the street, and I would never step foot in a Subway (outside of a cross country road trip out of desperation). $19 cheeseburger, + $2 for bacon, asked for medium-rare and got basically well done, deuce ordered medium and got grey. Couldn't even taste the blue cheese, probably strained chunks from a salad dressing jar. Fries were not cooked through and the onion ring batter had the mouth feel of velour. On top of that, the substituted rings were  $6 DOLLARS to sub (of course this wasn't mentioned by the server). The whole lunch, barring the $3 diet Coke and $3 iced tea, felt like it was summoned from either the frozen depths of the kitchen, or reheated rings and fries from earlier. Only upside, the pickles were good and the bartender and server were pleasant. I would not have eaten here if I knew it was a hotel (read, tourist trap), but Deuce works near by and thought "a $20 burger has to be good, right?"...wrong. $72 including tip for 2 below sub-par bacon cheeseburgers, substituted inedible onion rings and 2 non-alcoholic drinks...ridiculous.
author: Goose B.

description: Went here with the office on our last day of the summer program for breakfast.  They fit 18 of us around two tables on one wall, were fairly prompt with service, and the food was decent.  My only complaint is that it is kind of expensive.  To be fair, it's in a hotel, so what do you expect?  I mean, as the only place that actually can accomodate groups this large for breakfast in the financial district, no complaints.
author: Adam T.

description:
I came here to celebrate one of my best guy friend last night of debauchery before he leaves for law school. We were very late for our reservation but since we were an hour late the place was relatively empty. We only waited for 5 minutes because they had to set three more place setting because we had more people with us. Our server who had the Brooklyn accent was great. She was professional and patience. Patience because half of us were drunk already and ordering was an event. 
I ordered the 9oz. fillet Mignon and it was warm and bland. The carrots where good though for it was caramelized and the baked potato was so so. From the others who were close by me, they said the food was good but wish it was hotter then being warm. But at least our water glasses were always full and I have a saying, if my water glass is always filled then the place is good in my book.

So overall I give this place 3 stars.
One for the professional service from our Brooklyn server 
One for the excellent water server
One for their fast accommodation in getting our table together.
author: Kathy T.

description:
I feel American when I am here. This is what I assume traditional American restaurant is like. At the same time, I feel kinda old and boring. Yes, it is a good steak, though. 

 Filet mignon, 9oz, is about $49.  I think this is expensive for streak. It comes with whole carrot and potato cooked in your choice. The service, unlike many of the review, was nice. I did not have to reserve places cause FiDi is dead after 6:00pm The filet mignon was good but the potato and carrot was nothing special. I think this place offers good traditional American steak, but it lacks creativity for my taste. One time is good enough for places like this.
author: Mika G.

description:
Hire a Butcher

A group of us went to Bob's Chop House last night.  I ordered my favorite steak, the filet mignon.  I was not impressed that a $50 steak was not even trimmed.  I'm sorry, but nobody leaves the silver skin on a filet.  The toughness and shape of this "filet" led me to wonder if it even was a filet.  Normally restaurants of this caliber have access to prime cuts of meat but I suppose going with select helps keep costs down.  Other than the meat, the skillet potatoes were great and I did like the giant carrot.  I was surprised there was no desert, though.  The waiter was attentive but it sure was hard holding a conversation when every 2 minutes an arm was reaching over to replace the last sip of water you took.
author: Peter B.

description:
So, I have not written a Yelp review in ages. But, that said, Bob's inspired me.  The food in impecable, the portiones are HUGE. I split an entree and a salad and could barely walk out. 
If you are fortunate enough to have Shelly as your server, you are in for an experience that warrents a Yelp review.  She knows when to be at tableside and when to be absent.  Her wine recommendations are spot on.  Thank you for knowing your stuff, Shelly.
As I live in The City, I never would have picked Bob's for dinner, but with a friend visiting and staying at The Omni, I went along with his suggestion.  I was very surprised and delighted.
Fabulous beyond compare!
Thanks to Bob and to Shelly.
author: Matthew P.

description:
If you're looking for a steakhouse that will 'WOW' you, this place ain't it.

After reading some reviews and seeing the rating on citysearch.com, I had high hopes for this place to somehow pleansantly surprise me in some way, but the only thing that got surprised was my wallet, and it wasn't pleasant.

I had the filet and some bland sides that were obvious not so memorable.  The filet was pretty good, but I've definitely had better at restuarants that served really nice sides along with it.  The service wasn't that great either, it was very slow, and they weren't very attentive at all.

If you're willing to spend this kind of money, I'd recommend going to Ruth's Chris Steakhouse.
author: Sophia F.

description:
So I have been to many steakhouses, mostly in the south, but quite a few here in the city.  After having eaten at Bob's in Dallas, this one pales in comparison.

The steak was okay, it didn't really have that great steak flavor, must be why they put so much salt on the dish.  I literally thought I was eating from a salt shaker, me and my date.  The mash was good, the carrot, what is up with that!  The asparagus, yeah not so good.  It was overcooked and lacking all flavor.  The only way I knew I was really eating asparagus was the common odor one experiences hours later while visiting the little boys room!

To pricey for the goods...  There are other spots with a better piece of meat for the same $$$
author: Sam M.

description:
Every so often, my hubby and I like to indulge in a hearty steak meal.  There's no denying, we like our steak.  And we like it bloody - seriously, if we had our choice, we'd ask for it to be mooing.  

We've only been to Bob's twice.  But it's quickly becoming the top on our list, in terms of steakhouses.  

As for appetizers, the shrimp platter is a great appetizer to share among two or three people.  It comes cooked in three different styles, each one of them accentuating its own unique set of aromas, juicy flavors and textures in shrimp.  The crab cakes are  very nice (crispy on the outside) -  they're as good as the ones at Tadich Grill (on California street).  

The bread that they serve at Bob's is always warm and fresh.  It comes in the shape of sourdough, but is sweet and soft (and slightly chewy) in the inside like French bread.  Highly addictive - you don't even need butter or sauces to eat it, but if you DO have sauces, you must indulge.  

Now... on to the meat.

The first time we went, I ordered the 9 oz filet mignon, which was cooked to perfection.  It was tender, juicy, and delightfully tasty.  My hubby ordered the rack of lamb, which was juicy, favorful and moderately gamey (we like it gamey).   We would recommend trying it with the mint jelly, just to add to the taste and texture.

The second time we went, we graduated to the 20 oz. Prime "Cote de Boeuf," as recommended by our waiter.  It was juicy and tasty, but we prefered the filet mignon.  

The glazed carrot which accompanies the meal is prepared with a nice spicy flavor and the skillet fried potatoes topped with sauteed onions and peppercorn gravy are decadent and smooth.

The portions are BIG, so be prepared to fill your stomach in its entirety (or to take home some leftovers).  I would recommend the latter option.   I've never tried the desserts, because there has never been room.

Wait staff are friendly and attentive.  Highly recommended.
author: Natalie T.

description:
Premise:  Two stars for service, nothing memorable about this place other than the drunk woman from Idaho, Wisconsin...oh hell who knows where...she was AWESOME!

Began dinner with an order of the tomato and mozzarella salad, I've had better.  Nice portion however.  Main course consisted of the half duck with chip like potatoes covered in gravy and the signature phallic carrot.  The duck tasted like chicken, not "gamey" at all and a little crisper than I like.  The potato chips were...well...eh.  The carrot, huge in size but small in taste.

The saving grace of this experience other than the drunk woman was not only the wait staff, but the sundae.  ORDER IT!  Enough to please everyone at the table.  Good luck!
author: Shane P.

description:
I used to love this place until a recent visit when it felt as though I was in a hospital cafeteria. 

I came in for dinner around 8:30 and the dining room was so brightly lit with flourescent type lighting that it totally ruined the mood the decadent experience of a 10 oz. NY strip and a fully loaded baked potato washed down with a dark, choclately bordeaux. 

2nd buzz kill, the entire list was basically domestic wines. 

The steak was tremendous and my potato was as good as ever but the state of the dining room made it feel like I just ordered a steak at Denny's. 

The service was efficient and courteous but uninspired.
author: Sloane V.

description: been here twice....definitely a good steak joint....nothing fancy...just good USDA prime....dry aged beef.   I had the new york strip....very tender and tasty as you would expect from a true steak house.  The location and atmosphere is very dry though and feels cold. The place screams Hotel restaurant...very stiff, and old steakhouse feel...but it is nice!  i just dont know if i'd take a date here coz the ambiance is not romantic....more like a business meal with clients, eating a big piece of meat!
author: Erick P.

description: I was in bob's for lunch a week ago and the food was as exquisite as it can be. Also the service of a young server, Nataly was outstanding . When you are in Bobs you literally smell, taste and breath quality. Thank you.
author: John O.

description:
Disclaimer:  This may be not the most helpful review for most of you looking for guidance on Bob's since I was there for a business breakfast.  But, just in case you're looking for a Financial District breakfast spot, you may want to consider it.

Standard breakfast fare offered.  I had a three egg omelete which was overloaded with my selected fillings: cheese, bacon and onions.  My companion's oatmeal looked appetizing as well, and certainly healthier.  Service was attentive, but a little clueless when I asked for hot tea.

Overall, a fine business breakfast.
author: Ryan W.

description:
I was all excited to try the chicken fried steak for lunch, only to be rebuffed by its absence from the menu.  Instead, I ordered the fish and chips, and they were awful.  I know, what kind of idiot orders fish and chips at a steak house and then complains about it, but these were seriously bad.  Definitely worse than any of the fish and chips I've had at the bars in this town.  Soggy, limp batter seasoned with Lawry's seasoning salt.  Oversalted, lukewarm, flacid chips.  Not pretty.

On the other hand, I pretty much shit myself when I tried the Argentinean bread pudding.  I'm not sure what makes it Argentinean (caramel, bananas, vanilla ice cream?), but it was one of the best desserts in recent memory.  One star for the fish and chips + five stars for the bread pudding = three star average.
author: David C.

description:
I wouldn't dare eat a steak here with all the other options in town.

But the tiny little bar has some good points.  Nice wasabi peas and pistachios in the shell in cooler than cool Villeroy & Bosch serving dish.  Bartenders who know how to make a martini right.

Prices are insane out of this world ridiculous.  Mass market wine for $10-12 a glass that would cost $5-7 elsewhere.  The martinis are also twice normal price but they're at least twice normal size.  You can get totally blotzed from a single martini so I would stick with that.

And just outside the door they have a giant bowl of extra tasty jelly beans that make jelly belly taste like mouse turds, and a big serving spoon so people help themselves without spreading a virus.
author: Gil S.

description:
This place serves a mean steak.  I'm talking about one of the best steaks this side of Texas (which makes sense since this is the West Coast edition of the vaunted Texas restaurants of the same name).

But aside from the fantastic steak, the thing that gets the most comments has got to be the gigantic, radioactive carrot.  C'mon, where did they grow those things?  And how do they cook it all the way through without making the outside mushy?  Like the answer to the riddle of how many licks, the world may never know.

Anyhow, I gave it 4 stars because the service was just OK and the prices were a little steep.  But I can't really imagine anyone being disappointed by Bob's.

PROS:
- Great meat, cooked to perfection
- Gigantic carrot good for at least 10 minutes of conversation

CONS:
- High prices (especially on the booze, which is outrageous)
- Parking can be difficult
author: Drew P.

description: One of the best steaks I've had. Definitely a place to come back to again. The peppercorn gravy is awesome!
author: Richard G.

description: Very formal, not a casual, feel good place. Our waiter looked at us as if sizing up our billfolds. An awkwardly placed jar of grilled vegetables and brine greets you when you sit down for dinner. The waiter motioned to it as he sat us, so I felt obligated to eat a red pepper. It was kind of bland. He brought some bread over. The menu left me with sticker shock. I asked my friend if he wanted to leave, due to the prices. He beckoned me to stay put. I ordered the bone in rib eye and a salad of fresh mozzarella and tomatoes. The tomatoes were disappointing, unripe, and still that translucent orange. For $30 expected something a little more beautiful. Steak came and it was astounding. Cooked perfectly rare, as I like it, and the sear was crispy, rich and deep, as if coated in brown sugar. Garlic mashed potatoes were gorgeous and had an exceptional aroma and flavor.  Brown sugar coated carrot sat on the plate dead-center and had exceptionally delicious flavor and was cooked to perfection. I sampled my friend's dish and it was equally exquisite. Left almost in tears of joy.
author: Ezekiel S.

description:
Luckily, I go to steakhouses for the steak and here, Bob's did not disappoint: the bone-in rib eye was excellent, prepared as ordered. The rest though? The bread, while warm, was dry and basically seemed stale. They serve the steak with a huge carrot. Do I look like a bunny?! And the potatoes.. I had enough after one bite.

So if you're a steak minimalist, this place is ok but for a more complete experience, go elsewhere.
author: Jan Michael K.

description:
Great steak - - I had the 18 oz NY bone-in strip. Cooked perfectly and one of the best steaks I've ever had on the west coast.

Seafood (scampi) was mediocre. 

"Smashed" potatoes were good, but the grilled taters in brown sauce were a hot mess. Blecch! 

The enormous carrot, steeped in OJ and cinnamon and placed firmly in the middle of everything on the plate, has to go. By the end of the meal, the cinnamon had mingled with everything - it ruined the last portion of my steak, though the carrot itself tasted okay and was cooked perfectly. But what is it with that freakin' carrot? Of all the things to pick as a signature dish in a steak house?? 

Service was great. Wine list was extensive and relatively reasonable.


But the place is over-priced in general. Nearly $100/person with salad, wine, no cocktails, no coffee and no dessert. You can spend $90 on just a Porterhouse steak.

I doubt if I'll ever go back.
author: Don W.

description:
Is it the giant carrots? No. Although the signature glazed carrots at Bob's bring a new meaning to "girth."

I love the carrots and the meat offerings, but the other reason my husband and I come back to Bob's is the availablity of seating. Where else can you go for walk-in service AND get a fine dinner of luscious beef with all the sides -- and did I mention the ginormous carrots? 

A few years ago my husband and I decided to make a mission out of eating at every steakhouse listed in Zagat SF, and we did. For top quality we go to Ruth's, but you know, you have to make a reservation and all that. Every time we've wanted primo steak for dinner without fussing with reservations, we've gone to Bob's. And that's not knocking the food. Au contraire! We think it's a good secret, and I shouldn't even be writing about it.

Bob's gets another plus for semi-private booths on the side.

I've also always had very good service there. Hey, I was just there tonight! All in all, I would recommend Bob's in the Omni Hotel if you want great steaks and you simply cannot wait for something to open at Ruth's.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I kind of have mixed feelings about this place. I was meeting a high school friend in SF for dinner. We were both crazy hungry and craving some man food (steak 'n' potatoes), so we headed for Bob's.

My first impression of the place was, "Jeeze, this sure is ritzy for a place called 'Bob's!'"  We were greeted by a very professional hostess, who led us through the practically-empty restaurant to our table. There were three other people dining in the restaurant together at another table and a few guys catching a football game at the bar. It was only 7:00 on a Thursday night.

We had some bread, nothing to write home to mom about, but good. We were a little taken-aback by how expensive this place was, but figured it's a steak place and shrugged it off. We ordered the strip steak, scalloped potatoes and blue cheese salad.

The salad was good, again, not really a stand-out...but the steak was incredible!!! Made us regret sharing a plate because we only got to eat half of the succulent goodness!!! I swear I've never had a more tender, tasty steak in my whole life! I'm a fan, I'm sooo a fan...

But that brings me to the nastiness that arrived disguised as the scalloped potatoes: so you know what poker chips look like when they're stacked up? That's how the potatoes were arranged, sliced up and stacked on top of each other. They were dry, and the cheese wasn't creamy, it was dry too...almost like it was made from powder and water, and some cream was poured over the top.

We were so disappointed that, sadly, we ended up sending it back. The waiter was very kind and apologized profusely (you see, he explained that the dish was made from four types of gourmet cheese by a renowned chef). 

I won't go back again, even for the most insanely good steak I've ever tasted!
author: Manisha T.

description:
Everything at Bob's comes in Texas-sized portions- they're big on food and big on service! Bob's is top on my list for Bay Area steakhouses (Las Vegas's Gallagher's is number one overall for now). My wife and I had a great time and we ordered the following for dinner:

Calamari (us), Blue Cheese Salad (me), Tomato and Red Onions Salad (her), Porterhouse 12 oz. steak (her), Scallops with Spinach and Shiitake Mushrooms (me), Creamed Corn (me), and finally a Brownie Sundae (us). 

With my Texas-sized appetite, I even helped finished my wife's dishes. We only took home the dessert. Everything was incredibly tasty and we look forward to trying more. The Scallops was a special entree, so if you're down for just seafood, ask for it. The steak was just right, but I still miss Gallagher's. Regardless, I truly recommend Bob's- perfect for couples and small groups. They have an extensive cocktail and wine list. Try their Espresso or Chocolate Martinis.
author: Leroid D.

description:
I went in for a big lunch not to long ago and was expecting a fabulous, over-the-top meal, but maybe I was there on an off day.  

I started with the crab cobb salad to share with the table and then I ordered a kobe burger.  Then cobb was good and the burger was fine, not great, but cooked perfectly (I was expecting memorable).

One of my table mates ordered a steak which was over cooked not once, but twice.  So on the third try, the steak finally came out medium rare as ordered, but I realized that my lunch was now going on almost 2 hours.  I would say about a solid hour and half was spent sending back his steak and waiting.  

I'll give Bob's a try for dinner when I have time to sit for more than a couple of hours, but for lunch, it took way too long.
author: Valarie A.

description:
My good friend took me there for an early bday lunch last week and I have to say that although I love me my steak, it was not the best steak I've ever had.  I had the ribeye and and it was good, but not knock my socks off fantastic.  The phrase, 'a steak is a steak is a steak by any other name...'  comes to mind.. 
Not sure what happened, but the best steak I've ever had in my entire steak-eating life was actually at the Luxor Steakhouse in Vegas.  The prep was spot on, what can I say?  I've been ruined for all other steaks since..
If I had to choose a fave in the city here though, I'd say that Bobo's was up there and other places that I've been to to give you a small taste of my steak-eating repertoire - Harris', Smith & Wollensky, Bobo's...
Even my ribeye at Globe was a little bit better...
Maybe I need to go back to Bob's for the Filet..  Hmm..
author: Rose C R.

description:
I went here for a business lunch and this is one of the best steaks I've had in a long, long time; they really know how to do steaks.  They came on the plate sizzling with some butter, and perfectly medium rare, and the fat was crispy, just the way it should be.  The smashed potatoes were amazing as well.  I would have liked the creamed spinach better if it hadn't had that cheese crust on top of it, but that's OK.

Also, they mix a most excellent martini.

Steak and martinis together are some of the best things in life.

This is a classy place; white tablecloths, good bread, impeccable service.  Mind your manners and be prepared to spend big bucks.
author: Asteridae A.

description:
Great Filet and outstanding service. One of the few places you can go for lunch and actually have a conversation without raising your voice. Fantastic Veggie Club for non-flesh eaters.

Good Value!
author: Steve S.

description:
I came here for lunch and we were directed to their little side nook for dining. Apparently, no one can see us, including our waiter. I could understand that steakhouses are slower paced but our waiter took awhiiile to bring out our soda, didn't care to offer us bread while we waited over 20 minutes for our appetizer, a salad. When we had 1 bite of salad, a couple minutes later, someone was already bringing out our burgers. We sent the burgers back until are salad was almost finish. 
After conversing for what seemed like 30 minutes, we began drooling over the medium-well cooked KOBE burger! It was DELICIOUS! This  thick patty & cheese made a fine meal and was worth the $18!! It had me repeating "this is sooo good" while I devoured each juicy bite. I believe it was the best burger I've ever had.
author: Oanh N.

description: Food was great. Service was terrible-when we had the servers attention at all. Server was clearly slammed when we were seated. Tried to rush us into an order. Didn't even ask if we wanted a drink to start. But the place cleared out, still had a *very difficult* time even getting to our table. Waited 30 for her to even notice that we'd just been sitting there waiting to ask to take the rest home. They remembered my note about my wife's bday, that was nice. But then took forever to get a check. Host was excellent. Food was excellent. Doorman was excellent-he and the host deserve the server's tip. Locals-don't bother with here. Harris' is 1000x better. Should have gone there. Just wanted one more steak alternative in the city. This isn't it.
author: Sbicy Meatball J.

description: The best steak I EVER had was at the Bob's Steak and Chop House in Dallas. So having moved to the bay area recently, my wife and I had dinner at the Bob's in San Fran for our anniversary. Unfortunately, neither her filet mignon or my steak was anywhere near as good as the ones in Dallas. We still had a good time but I would attribute that more to wonderful company and good wine. If you're ever in Dallas, go to the Bob's there and see if you don't start crying over your steak...it's that good!! I'm giving them four stars for their customer service.
author: Jerry J.

description: Nice location, very helpful staff. The steak was pretty weak though. Had the filet, not horrible but it was a bit on the dry side, but there are just too many excellent steak houses in the city to eat here, especially for the price. Colleague did say Salmon was good. Not a big fan of the carrot, makes everything on the plate taste like its seasoning. Bleu cheese salad is pretty good.
author: Arturo H.

description:
So we end up here because of what happened at Sam's, see my review over there, and I would not have picked this place myself, but I'd never tried it so what the hell, right? No. 

This place is from some distant forgotten decade where overcooking and extra butter is the key to everything. The bread isn't even good SF sourdough! The martini's have ice chips in them, which I routinely forgive at a crowded bar but the dining room was almost empty and come on, this is the Omni! I expect more... This was about 8:45pm on a Tuesday. They don't know what the word "seasonal" means, I'm sure. 

The busser who poured our waters told me the fish of the day was Ahi Tuna, and when the waiter comes and I order it, he does not apologize that his restaurnt gave me misinformation, but instead is rather indignant about it, like, how dare I tell him what the special is! (eye-rolling here). 

I can't remember exactly what we ordered, but I remember this -  the spinage, the mushrooms, the bread, a straight vodka martini, a chocolate martini, asparagus salad, apple sauce, soup, another salad.
author: Alexandria N.

description: Go for the steak - but nothing else. Even the bread was average. Problem with this place is it's in the Omni Hotel - so the prices are over the top. $56 for a steak!
author: Peter S.

description:
When I think about getting a nice steak dinner in San Francisco, this is usually the place I go.  Bob's steaks are freaking mind blowing. 

Found off the lobby of the Omni hotel, this place is one of the top ranked steak places in the nation. It's one of those nice but semi casual places where you don't feel under-dressed if you don't have a sport coat on yet you still feel fancy 'cause you're eating there. 

I go in there, order the New York steak and I never once have been disappointed. No frills with the steaks, they don't have any special gimmick or what not, they just know what they're doing in there. 

Great place to have a nice, full dinner, drinks. Just a classy spot. 


I don't know what the deal with the carrot is though.
author: Andy A.

description:
Ok - decided to have a going away event for a co-worker at Bob's.  Yeah, I know this place is in a Hotel and the ambiance is for the "blue-bloods".  What can I do, I needed a table for 10 people on short notice.  That being said, this is not the place for a big blow-out with a bunch of people with loud mouths.  It is a prim a proper place for a nice little old couple.  So the ambiance could use some work, we all know that (well you do now ;o).....

Our crew ordered the Nickel Nickel Cabernet (always a good start).  I highly recommend.  For appetizers I suggested (yes I will take the credit) some lobsters to split for the table.  An excellent suggestion I must admit.  For dinner I decided on the "strip" and what a selection.  It was cooked to perfection (medium rare charred) and oh so delish.  I highly recommend.  Side was some potatoe nonsense - kind of sucked and our sides were ok at best.  Dessert was standard fare.. but definitely stop in for the strip.
author: Tom C.

description:
I can't say that the food we had was bad. I was just average and clearly overpriced. First, the location: this restaurant is in the financial district, inside a high end hotel. My theory is that most of their clientele is traveling for business and just expensing their meal, which explains why this restaurant can charge around $40 for an average steak.

Our server was incredibly unhelpful, almost rude, which of course didn't help. But I will refrain from drawing any conclusion about the service in general. Just be ready and don't expect a place that provides stellar service.
author: Alessandro V.

description:
The decor may be a little old school but they have no dress code so I wouldn't categorize this place as 'stuffy'. Looking past this, the service was impeccable. The host greeted and seated us but I soon realized the the window seat was way too cold for me, so they happily moved us to the 'best booth in the house'. Our server was attentive and so were the three other busboys that came by to check up on us. The food was amazing; I simply loved the way they prepared my Filet Mignon - medium rare...cooked just the way I asked for. We asked for the sliced potatoes with onions and gravy...and that was a treat! 

I'll give an almost perfect 5 star rating but the only thing I wasn't impressed with is the pickled pepper & pickle dish they served in a jar that sat on the table. Nothing special and takes away from the 'experience'. 

I'll definitely be back when I have a steak craving. And definitely recommend if you're willing to throw down some cash. Net net, it's stiff pretty affordable though and worth it for a nice dinner.
author: Hazel S.

description:
I've been to many steak houses, most of the ones worth eating at in SF and beyond.  The selection of meat is better than anywhere I've eaten, including Smith and Wolensky's (though they are damn good as well).  A nice variety of cuts to satisfy every palet!  The decor is very typical of a steak house, not too much to write home about, BUT they have a few private tables which makes the experience that much more personal and enjoyable.
Their wine and champange list is superb.  And for not having a sommelier they're staff is pretty good at suggesting the perfect wine for what you're having.  I know, you're thinking, steak house, umm red wine! but they go quite a bit past that.  The suggestion they made for us has become a feature wine at our house wine parties.
Check out Bob's, you definitely won't be disappointed.
author: Buster K.

description:
All i remember is that they have the best steak ever! place is really pricey but the flavor of the steak is amazing. their sauteed mushrooms were also good. 

when i ate here, they were shooting Pursuit of Happyness a block away so that added to the excitement.
author: Douglas F.

description:
When Mike said OMG thats such a big carrot and I'M SO EXCITED!  Everyone at the table couldn't contain themselves - Rey & I thought that the waitress was going to drop the rest of our food.  It was the funniest thing.  

Rey & I met Buster, Joey, Steve & Mike here last night.  The steaks were amazing especially the "Cote de boeuf" Prime Bone-in Rib Eye.  It was so delicious.  This place is really worth coming too especially for the sour balls that is between the bar and restaurant!
author: May A.

description:
I'm from Dallas, and every year for more than ten years we would have one of our holiday family parties at Bob's.  The food is amazing, although our cardiologist's might not agree.. the onion rings (or is that an onion loaf?) are fantastic, and I don't think I've ever had a better steak elsewhere. 
The HUGE carrot alongside your steak has been a mainstay forever (I can remember when that thing seemed larger than my head!). 

Walking into Bob's, whether it is Dallas or San Francisco, brings back so many great memories.. The food is always fantastic, and the service makes you feel like a million bucks.
author: Stacy S.

description:
I was at the table with Shane P. and yes the service was good.
We started with an Onion Ring and the Crab Cake appetizer.
(Notice no S on the word CAKE.)  I didn't when I read the menu.
however, it was the most crab i've ever had in a Crab Cake, but the sauce no so tasty in my opnion...a sweet horseradish-like sauce...
Onion Rings are probably the best one's i've ever had.  I don't know where they get them Huge onions, but Damn they are good.

I skipped salad, well cause I came for steak not salad.
My Rib Eye was so melt-in-your-mouth yummy, but the potatoes were less than par for Bob's.  I've had the Fried potato with peppercorn gravy many times, and this was my least favorite.

Now the Brownie SUndae with the Peanut Butter Cup ice cream, which I wasn't really hungry enough to have...but oh thank God I did.
some of the best ice cream i've ever eaten in my life.

I will be back again.

Hopefully the drunk lady will not be there next time...Her cackle got on my nerve.
author: James R.

description:
I would have to agree with the lot of people who's review says, "overpriced".  Yes, for what you get it's overpriced.  The filet mignon I had for dinner was quite tasty, along with the carrot and mashed potatoes.  But, was it worth the price? I don't think so.  I think if they lower their price (ha!), I'd return.

The service was good.  I thought that our waitress was quite accommodating and pleasant to talk to.

I think you'll find better bang for your buck at either Morton's or Ruth's Chris.
author: Christopher C.

description: They had great service, friendly staff, and peaceful ambiance to ring in 2011. I really want to come back for dinner!
author: Hannah N.

description: Popped in for lunch the other day with a friend. They were a little busy but sat us right away. Was hoping to find something light (in a steak house) . Opted for the Cobb Salad with Chicken. Requested a coupl emenu modifications. It was made to order in a timely manner and was yummy! Our server was very nice and had us out of there in an hour.
author: Wendy R.

description: I went here for my company Christmas party a year ago and it was totally disappointing.  I am someone who loves steak and meat.  I also love a good baked potato and hearty veggies.  Our table was restricted to a prix fix holiday menu.  I had a filet mignon that was ok but nothing to write home about.  The whole carrot is just strange.  I'm not sure why anyone would want to eat a carrot that way.  Our table had some onion rings that were pretty tasty at least.  I suppose I'm a tough grader when it comes to steakhouses because there was nothing bad about our food and the service was good anyway.  The whole experience just didn't work for me though.
author: Laura B.

description: We were very disappointed at this resturant. We ordered the chophouse salad it was from a package mix lettuce and for $11.00 they mix it together to make it look like its not from a mix. The $53.00 new york steak was not melt in your mouth you get a huge carrot in the middle, and the potatoes were ok, slouthered with gravy. They should not be charging what they do for the meals, it is a rip off. Wait persons were not very informative.
author: Nicchi S.

description:
When I rate a restaurant I compare it to other places that are in the same price range and cuisine so this place only gets 2 stars.  Compared to Ruth's Chris and Boboquivari's, Bob's is horrible.  I went with 2 buddies and we each got a different cut.  NY, ribeye and the filet.  The only one that was halfway decent was the filet ... but it was also $50 for 12 ounces.  My NY came out way over cooked so they cooked another one for me.  The second attempt was cooked right, but the steak itself was tough and lacked flavor.
