Whatever you do don't get the potato things with sauce and onions or whatever they call it.  The sauce runs past the big carrot and into you steak section.  Get the baked potato instead.

At the prices they charge it should be a lot better.  Ruth's and Bobo's don't have much to worry about in SF.
author: James F.

description:
We stayed at the Omni and were too tired after a long day of shopping and sightseeing to actually go down to the restaurant, so we ordered room service.  We got the 9oz Filet and Pork Chops.  Our sides were Glazed Carrots, Sauted Spinach and Mushrooms, Skillet Potatoes, and a Baked Potato.  First the room service did not bring up our pork chops due to a mix up when ordering (I suppose).  But they brought the chops up a few minutes later, with complimentary sodas and cookies to smooth things over (We were sufficiently smoothed over).

The steak and chops were cooked perfectly.  The skillet potatoes were "different," and I am doubtful I will order them again.  They were potato rounds fried so they were crispy but them covered with a thick gravy.  Sounds good, well it sorta was.

Next time we plan on dining in the restaurant.  The food was delicious.
author: Phil V.

description: I love love this place! Dark and romsantic! Tall booths. The food is very good too! Had the special bacon wrapped quail for app & steak for dinner! Perfect every thing was perfect!!!
author: Dustee M.

description: Excellent EVERYTHING.  Came here to treat the boy for his birthday.  I warned him ahead of time that it will be a lot of steak, so no appetizers, and hold back on the bread!  We shared a pickle from the jar, but don't bother--tasteless, even saltless!  Bread was steaming hot...crusty outside, soft inside, but skip this too.  Just feast on the steak deliciousness.  We both had the bone-in ribeye ($58).  I had mine with the skillet potatoes.  Steak was awesome.  Juicy, and seasoned nicely, although a little too salty.  The potatoes were tasty--crispy + smothered with onions and gravy.  Carrot was OK.  I couldn't finish my steak.  The boyfriend loved it so much he ate his and finished mine.  Meat heaven.  It's pricey for steak, but I went in with this expectation, so I think it's worth every penny.  Service is excellent, too.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Over priced and over rated.  I have eaten many a glorious prime steak in my life and I'll tell you what, this ain't it.  The hostess was polite and offered us a lovely table by the window.  Our server arrived telling of the specials and taking our drink order.  After much deliberation we order the blue cheese salad, very good and the bone-in ribeye which was just aight.  The steak was overcooked and dare I say, not the quality I expect of a prime steak nor worthy of the $55 price tag.  The smashed potatoes were very good too.  At the end my husband and I were very happy to have not gone w/ the big daddy of steaks for $65, as he would have been PIIIIIIIIIIIIIISED if that had arrived overcooked and under seasoned.
author: Heather S.

description: I probably would've never eaten here had it not been for the open table deal, $25 for $50 of food. I mistakenly thought the entrees would be roughly in the $30 range, so I was a little disappointed that my $50 deal would only cover one person's dinner. But whatever, it's a steakhouse, and I was ready to eat meat. We started with the soup of the day, lobster bisque. Our waiter offered to split it into two dishes since we mentioned we were just going to share. The half portion we each got seemed like it was a full portion, that was a nice surprise. The soup was amazing, full of flavor, absolutely delicious. I cleaned my plate with my bread, not leaving a drop behind. My bf said he could just eat another bowl of the soup and call that dinner. I ordered the rack of lamb, which was cooked perfectly, still pink inside, not too gamey, and super tender. The bf got the salmon, it was melt in your mouth, perfectly cooked delicious buttery flakey fish goodness. The baked potato comes with your choice of toppings that they bring to the table - green onions, bacon, cheddar, sour cream. Yum. I got the smashed potatoes (which are just mashed potatoes, not sure why they say smashed), also yummy garlicky deliciousness. I didn't care for the giant glazed carrot, but the bf ate it up, and he usually hates cooked vegetables. Our waiter was friendly and helpful, and didn't wrinkle his nose at the coupon, which I kind of expect at nicer places. All in all, it's an expensive steak house, it's quiet, the ambiance isn't that great (full of older men in suits), but the food was damn good. I'd go back just for that lobster bisque.
author: Sophie P.

description:
Recently went for dinner with half a dozen friends.  It was fine.  

My "blue cheese salad" wasn't worth the effort.  In fact, it was strangely so cold that it's temperature pretty much overwhelmed any flavor.  A friend had the crab cake...  very good, I wish I'd have ordered it, too.  

For my entree I had the KC ribeye...  I liked the spicing and it was cooked well.  It tasted good, but wasn't really memorable.  I've had many better, but it certainly wasn't disappointing.  After a few bites as-is, I got a side of the peppercorn sauce, and I actually thought that was pretty good.  I was expecting something thicker, but it was more like an Au Jus.  The baked potato wasn't anything special.  For desert we got the the Argentinian bread pudding, and this gigantic brownie sunday thing.  Both were good but, again, unspectacular.  

Unfortunately, that was kind of the theme.  I had a great time with my friends, and appreciated that the restaurant allowed us to have a leisurely 3+ hour dinner.  Then again, the only thing truly memorable was the company.  There really isn't any ambiance; it's just a very basic setting in a hotel.  And it wasn't cheap...  my rib eye was $50, and a porterhouse would have run you $70.  At those price points, I won't be going out of my way to go back.
author: Jeff T.

description:
We had a nice lunch in a relaxed, white table cloth dining room. Service was very good, efficient but not overly so. We all had hamburgers which albeit were a little pricey (15) they were prime meat and delicious. Comes with salad or potatoes.  
Good place to eat in the financial district- it's in the lobby of the Omni Hotel on the corner of Calif and Montgomery.
author: Mike L.

description: We had Christmas dinner there this year.  The place was packed!  We both had the bone in Rib Eye Steak which was WONDERFUL. Service was rather slow at times. Valet parking is $15.
author: Bill F.

description:
A "local" told us this was considered one of the better steak houses in SF...since we were staying at the Omni we gave it a shot.

Mistake...our source has obviously never been to a few of the steak houses in SoCal...the steak was kinda tough if I recall and the sides were just kind of blah...hard to describe...and the joint was EMPTY.

Should've researched steak options on my own first but went with the recommendation...turns out there is a steak house in the Marina district someone else raves about (the name escapes me)...will prob try that next time we're in the Bay Area...
author: Michael P.

description:
Went there for dinner last night with a few co-workers and I must say, it was pretty good.  I had the spinach salad with poppy seed dressing and the bone in rib-eye steak with baked potato.  Salad was tasty.  the crispy bacon bits in it made it all so much yummier.  My steak was cooked to perfection while my baked potato and glazed carrot was just ok.  The food could have been warmer.  Perhaps they cooked my steak first before the others.  It was still good but I like my meat nice and hot like at Ruth Chris'.

Our server was very nice and did a great job with helping us pick out our cuts of meat (depending on our appetites) and our wine.  Overall dinner experience was pretty good.  If you're a steak person, give this place a try.  I wouldn't say it's the best in the city but if you happen to be in the neighborhood and don't mind blowing $50 on a 20oz rib-eye then Bob's is the place for you.  Would I come back?  Sure.
author: Billy T.

description:
Great 30th anniversity meal with my wife. The Fillet was absolutely the best we have had since we moved from the midwest 25 years ago. It was cooked perfectly medium rare, and had a very flavorful crust. The service was excellent. The only minus was the bread. It was freshly baked, but had no flavor. 

Expensive, but we would go again.
author: Paul F.

description:
where fidi suits power-lunch.  bob's has a men's club feel, with dark wood and colors dominating the decor, plus little booths tucked here and there for some privacy (for those top secret deals!)  gracious service.

they make a decent burger and my coworkers used to rave about their cobb salad years ago, but the last time i went the salad seemed a bit skimpy compared to previous servings - has america finally stopped supersizing everything food related?

it's still a good salad - generous topping of sweet dungeness crab a nice addition to the usual cobb fixins - cheese, egg, bacon and greens mixed in a tasty vinaigrette.

one of these days i'll try a steak or chop...
author: Jen P.

description: Was prepared for a mediocre hotel breakfast yesterday and was very pleasantly surprised!  Food was beautifully presented, perfectly cooked, and quite delicious.  My daughter and I shared the ham, egg & cheese sandwich and the Belgian waffle.  Food was just a tad slow coming out of the kitchen, but other than that, no complaints!
author: Gwen G.

description:
Best steak in the city.  The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 stars is the environment.  REALLY stuffy crowd but if you can go with good friends and ignore the group around you (unless you look like the group around you, no offense if you do), it won't disappoint.  

My question is, where else would you go for great bone in rib eye?  Ruth Chris?  please
author: peter k.

description: This review is for the lounge only... Prices might initially be shocking but once you realize that you get a double pour of whatever wine or alcohol you order you might understand. Good  for happy hours and game watching. Also they have a super gorgeous server there on Sat nights...
author: kenny d.

description:
My 1st time here and 2nd time to a steak house.
Went here after I had a few drinks at the Cosmopolitan Cafe earlier in the evening.
+1 for Bob's being open till 10pm on a weekday.
The service is excellent as our waiter was very attentive and made excellent suggestions in regards as to which one would go best with what meal.
The dessert was excellent... I mean, how can a chocolate cake be bad, but this cake was rich, smooth and ohhhhh soooo good!
I ordered: 
appetizer: the crabcake along with a white wine suggested by the server.
main course: the house prime rib with the smashed potatoes. I found this steak to be very flavorful which lasted till every bite unlike the porterhouse I had at Harris'. Also, the waiter suggested a very tasty Merlot to go with the steak. It was tasty to me as I never drink Merlot.
Dessert: the chocolate cake! Now that's a dessert.
I definitely recommend this place and will be back there again.

EDIT:
DO NOT order the asparagus salad. DAMN what a $9 dissapointment that thing was. Really. It was a plain old $3 iceberg lettuce with some tomatoes, avocado, mushrooms and asparagus on top.

Also, the GF was a bit disappointed in the over quality of the meal as she felt for the price it should have been better.
author: Paul U.

description: I was maybe a little delirious when I came here for dinner, as I'd been working practically nonstop for 2.5 weeks and was running on very little sleep, so I think any restaurant I visited while in that state would have to be amaaaaazing for me to really come away with a good impression.  Having said that, Bob's was just okay.  Calamari were tasty.  My strip steak was cooked nicely, and I definitely requested that the glazed carrot be left off of my plate.  The bread was kind of awkward though, in that it's not even partially sliced for you, so someone (or everyone) has to manhandle the bread if you're dining with a group.  Loved that they had a jar of pickles at the table though, I thought that was a nice touch!
author: Mousputin S.

description: BREAD!!! Yummy, warm, soft, fluffy and delicious BREAD! If you don't explode from over-indulging in bread before ordering...then you may want to order a steak because they are equally as delicious. Tender chunks of well cooked beef practically melt in your mouth and when combined with fluffy, smooth smashed potatoes its hard not to have a little bit of an orgasm in your mouth. The only downside is the prices are a bit steep. I was on vacation in San Fran so I splurged a bit and I am so glad I did. If you are penny pinching, share the 12 ounce with a friend. With the generous portion of smashed potatoes and all the bread you will eat...it should be plenty of food.
author: Vee B.

description: great place to grab some drinks and a giant piece of meat after work! The bone in rib eye is bomb! Big bomb! Steaks come with sides of grubbin fried potatoes with gravy and a (what the?) carrot I just shoved to the side of my plate.
author: Peter M.

description: Came here for valentines day with the boo.., service was great And the waiter gave me a rose!!! The boo, we first had the jumbo shrimp app. Very good but only came with 4 for 17$ then we both had the filet .. All I have to say is that's the best steak I have had in my life! Def. Recommend but be preparred to spend some money !! 160 for 2 people for 2 steaks 2 glasses if wine n a appetzer but I will def be back
author: Shauna P.

description:
my b f told me he was  takin me out  to din & I ask where . He say Bobs Chop house  & I was like oh no  u dint.

but hey it ios NOT what it sounds like. this is a Really nice restrant w/ dress  code and tablecloths in a beautful hotel  And I had a perfect sir;loin. minus 1 star for a bitchy  waiter i wanted to slap

i love it when my bf does good
author: Farajaqua S.

description:
This is my litmus test for great service and you can see this in my other reviews: dress like a bum.

I came here with my friend who just got off work and did not have an opportunity to change. He works in construction and had paint all over his attire. The service was just as good as when I went there for my gf's birthday. 

One time my steak came undercooked (the server claimed, but did not insist, that I ordered the steak rare). My friend bet me that they would re-cook and bring out the same steak, which is the practice of other steakhouses. Needless to say, my friend lost bigtime.
author: Ken L.

description: Yes, yes, oh God yes!  I've only been here once but when I went I had the pork chops, baked potato and broccoli.  The chops came with homemade apple sauce, damn it was so good.  Maybe it was the wine or the fried calamari but I felt like "God must feel when he holds a gun".  Everything tasted great except for the pickles.  They have a jar of pickles on the table but they didn't taste that good.  They weren't sour pickles but just like pickles without any flavor.  No big deal though everything else was amazing.
author: Bean S.

description: I had heard Bob's, despite being a chain, was the best steakhouse in Dallas. I would also guess that Texans know steak. However, I didn't think my experience was anything that special. For the price, I'd go to Harris's or Bobo's.
author: Nish N.

description:
Our group of 5 came to Bob's on a Monday night.  4 of us arrived on time but were missing the last person from our group.  Our waiter came over and asked if the last person was coming and we told him yes, he's on his way and will be a bit late.  He seemed annoyed by that.  We told him we could order first and let him order when he shows up.  Our waiter said "that would mess things up."  Sorry Bob, we'll try to be more punctual next time.   

The food: Calamari was good.  Although it's fried, it wasn't greasy at all.  

Salad was so-so.  

Our rib-eye steaks were awesome.  The meat felt like it melts in your mouth.  The potato.... not so great.  A bit too salty and too much butter used.

Dessert: Chocolate cake was surprisingly moist.  Huge portion.  Didn't like the cheesecake as much.   

Overall, it's very pricey.  Had our waiter been more patient with us, it would be a much more pleasant experience.  Sorry Bob, I'll probably have to think twice before dropping $300 on you again.
author: D L.

description: A little stuffy, but it's a decent place for an after-work drink or meal.  They make a good martini, but what really keeps me coming back are the onion rings.  They are the size of donuts - no really, I'm not exaggerating, I said DONUTS! and are served freshly fried.  Just make sure when you order them you ask for dijon mustard - they're so much better that way!
author: Erica G.

description: Ok- all we had was a business meeting with some drinks at this joint. We talked some good biz and had some Arnold Palmers 1/2 lemonade and 1/2 ice tea. Am I pushing 60 years old here folks? Those are great tasty beverages, and the service was 3 snaps up- but come on now, Arnold Palmers? I need something with some kick in my drink- especially if it's after 3:00 p.m. - mmmkay... Candy is dandy, but liquor is quicker. Next time I'll try the Arnie Palmer Martini- if there's such a thing? I bet they can make one up.
author: Braden B.

description:
I went here with a couple friends on the 4th of July because we weren't in the mood to organize a BBQ, but couldn't resist a large hunk of meat.  All the other steakhouses in San Francisco were booked, so I was only able to make a reservation at Bob's.  I was excited by the thought of the phallic pickles and carrots mentioned in the other Yelp reviews, but that is the only appeal this place has to me now.  

Their rib eye was mediocre and not worth the price.  I was even more disappointed by their side dishes.  I'm a huge fan of creamed spinach and was expecting something similar to the spinach at the House of Prime Rib, but instead of a savory, creamy goodness, I was served a strangely sweet, cinnamon flavored concoction.  The carrot was overly sweet also and the skillet potatoes were lacking in flavor.

I don't hate this place, I probably just wouldn't go there again.
author: Alice T.

description: Ate lunch here with a group of 11.  The service was very good, but the five minute delay after delivery of the first half of the entrees created that awkward, "No, go ahead and start--don't wait for us, your food will get cold," moment.  I had the "special" wedge salad and flat iron steak.  The lettuce smelled slightly less than fresh and the dressing was a bit runny.  The steak was definitely not medium-rare as I ordered, but more on the medium-well side.  It was very tasty nonetheless.  Overall it was a good, but not great experience.  I was expecting greatness.  I will likely give Bob's another try, next time for dinner service.
author: Daryl E.

description: Just on my list because I've eaten here.  Nothing bad but really nothing special about this place at all.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: Bob has great steak (filet mignon). Bob has great service. Bob has plain, boring salads. Bob has a pretty bland atmosphere. Bob is expensive for what he offers.
author: Rada I.

description:
This IS A GOOD STEAK HOUSE people, they have good steaks. Service here might not always be the best but I've been there for almost 10 times and no one was ever rude to me, or took too long to serve me. And one thing you can count on Bob's is that they'll always have a seat for you, even on those days that other steaks houses are jam packed. That's what I like about them, I never had to wait for more than 5 minutes to sit down, with reservation or no reservation. This is very important to me because I feel like nothing is worth me waiting for an hour, I don't care about good the place is. But anyways, let's get back to their food. 
Prime (or bone in) Rib-Eye - Very good
Rack of Lamb - Very good
Veal Chop - Very good
Appetizers - Average
Glazed Carrot - (somewhat different) but good
Scallop Potato - Not all that, I would have the bake potato instead 
Bottom line, if you want a good piece of steak, you can find it here, if your looking for superior service, maybe you should try an expensive French restaurant.
author: Wes Z.

description: Bone-in Ribeye Steak (aka Prime "Cote de Boeuf") and 18 year old scotch never tasted so good.  Great place to go if you want an uncrowded dining experience on a Monday night.  The service was a bit slow but given that I was there for a meeting, I didn't mind it so much.
author: Hector M.

description:
i'm not big on steak, so i usually check out the menu online beforehand if i know i'm going to a steakhouse.  and they actually have decent non-steak options like lamb, duck, shrimp and crab cakes.  i went with the crab cakes.  and they were decent.  not at all phenomenal, but decent.  and their sides are good.

i definitely wouldn't request to come here, but it's decent for business meals and at least i know there'll be something i'll like on the menu.
author: spiff e.

description: Five star for the meat, for the Bone-In Rib-Eye and the Filet Mignon. Got the filet over NY considering this steakhouse is known for their Mignon. The carrot is strangely sweet and did not compliment the meal. The sides were also only half decent. Great two choices of meat, down one star because of the sides. Also a bit pricey, might try the fish next time but the Mignon is worth going back for.
author: Natasha S.

description: This place has the best bone-in ribeye steak called the Coute de Boeuf. They also have a good appetizer list but I hear they don't have those big loafs of bread anymore. Also, the oversized carrots are a good surprise if  you haven't seen that before.
author: Glenn Z.

description: I've eaten at Bob's 3 times now and this latest visit warranted a very positive review. I had the massive Chicken Fried Rib eye steak with Smashed Potatoes. It was perfect in all respects. The steak was a melt in your mouth masterpiece as was the gravy the steak was slathered in. I've been disappointed with my previous visits. The Penne Pasta w/Chicken Breast and the Dungeness Crab salad were not of the caliber one expects from a restaurant in the city. But I now know, when you are at a steakhouse order the steak!
author: D Scott D.

description: LOVE! My hubby's measuring stick for all steakhouses now. He orders their "Cote de Boeuf" that's what they are known for. I ordered the filet mignon. They know their steak - delicious!
author: Carmelina A.

description: Bob's is rumored to be the best steak house in San Francisco but my vote still goes to House of Prime Rib when I need a beef fix. My fiancee is a die hard fan of Bob's and makes regular dates with the boys there so they can feast on bloody red meat in the lounge, drink scotch and go ARRR at the flat screen TVs featuring the sporting event of the evening. I had the petite filet, and the fried potatoes smothered in gravy and onions. I shudder at the thought of the levels of octane-charged potatoes I consumed that evening. This is definitely a man's place, complete with dark wood paneled walls and phallic six inch pickles in jars and monster carrot on your plate to go with your bloody steak.
author: Jess H.

description: Compared to other steakhouses in the area, Bob's falls short on service in the bar area. It took forever to get the waitresses attention and when we needed her she was off puttering around in the corner of the bar doing nothing. The sliders were mediocre, but the shrimp cocktail and the onion rings are tasty.
author: Stacy T.

description: The steak here is awesome. Always cooked to perfection! Yes a little pricey but what do you expect for great, quality steak? The decor is very classic but new San Francisco... kinda makes you want to order some Scotch neat! I've had the Filet, and the T-bone and both are great! In San Francisco Bob's and Harris' are my fav!
author: Christine L.

description: First time here.  Had a drink in the bar which was really crowded.  Not the best service in there and the drinks are pricey.  Off to the restaurant for dinner.  What a difference...The server was fantastic, and everyone was out to make the experience great. We had the fried calamari first which was absolutely fantastic.  The only problem is that they served it with cocktail sauce(I am an east coast transplant and calamari is usually served with marinara sauce)  I politely asked if there was any tartar sauce or other type of sauce.  Our server came back with house made remoulade sauce which was to die for. Ordered the filet mignon which was perfect.  My partner had the ribeye which he said was wonderful.  We ordered the onion rings(trust me get the half sized portion) and they were amazing. I reserved the table on opentable and mentioned it was for a birthday.  Nobody mentioned anything, so I wasnt sure they read my mention , and decided not to say anything, but after our meal they came out with a brownie sundae for my partner with a candle on it!! And it was on the house.  Nicely done, Bob's, nicely done!!
author: Matt S.

description: As said, it's a bit stuffy but it's still good. It doesn't get all 5 stars because my baby is Ruth's Chris. The service at Bob's, however, makes you feel like you're worth 1 TRILLION dollars. Definitely a plus when you're celebrating your birthday. I highly recommend the potato chips. They're amazing...and I don't really like potato chips. Make a lunch reservation, order an Arnold Palmer, a steak and potato chips and then make sure you have an afternoon spot reserved for your food coma. Umm...steak.
author: Cassy R.

description: I am sorry I didn't take pictures of my meal; the pictures would have been enough of a review. $10 chopped salad was a fistful of chopped romaine with some bits of chopped extras hidden below. $50 petite filet was plated just like this: piece of beef, grotesquely large whole carrot, baked potato. It was presented with no more care than a tired mom trying to rush dinner on the table.  Steak was excellent, but at these prices, in such a food centric city, I honestly don't know why anyone would bother to go here, unless they were a guest at the Omni, too exhausted to walk even one block for a meal prepared with more skill and care.
author: Ellen W.

description: Hands down my favorite steak restaurant!  The prices are close to Ruth's Chris, but Bob's steaks do include a potato side dish and a big glazed carrot.  Ruth's Chris doesn't include any sides.  All of the salads and side dishes here are large enough for 2-3 people to share.  The key lime pie is fantastic, they have nilla wafer crust instead of the standard graham cracker and it's big enough for 2 people.  Each time I've gone the service has been great and my first time there the manager gave us a free creme brulee for our first visit.
author: Krystal K.

description: This place was another pricey destination for a department luncheon. It is a really nice restaurant. I ordered the filet mignon and it was good, but a bit tough, which I find amazing cause it is filet mignon! But altogether it was a good dining experience and the deserts are really amazing. If ya got the money for it, check this place out!
author: Tyler D.

description: this is old school lunch business meeting spot, but they make a pretty decent burger for the financial district.  i've also tried the crab salad that's pretty fresh and and hearty.
author: Helen T.

description: What I'm really talking about is the Bar NEXT to the restaurant, but whatever.  This bar is in the Omni and has great window seats for lunchtime financial district people watching.  Twice I've spotted people from my hometown just strolling by, tourists...But I digress.  This place has excellent food but it is $$$$ for a lunch spot.  The crab cobb salad will make you weep, cause it's good and cause it's $20.  If you're expensing it, this is an excellent place to take clients...otherwise, the view isn't worth the price.
author: Claire C.

description: Bob's is still a great lunch place in my book. Its always filled with the corporate monkeys and some occassional tourists. The service at Bob's is always fast and attentive and I have never been disappointed withy my food. The fish and chips are are plentiful there and definately YUMO!
author: Julie F.

description:
forgot to cover this when i made my original steak list but i still remember my experience here well!  

man what a cardinal sin!  they have some high quality steaks but mess it up by overseasoning it!  BOOOOO to YOU BOB!  anyways, last time i went i asked thme to ease up on the salt and things turned out pretty great.  the glazed carrot side is one of the best sides i've ever had w/ steak.

other than food issues, this is a great place to come w/ a group of co-workers as the place totally caters for groups and has great service to back em up.  i feel bad for the 3 stars but the salty steaks just is too much to turn a blind eye to.
author: Swarup B.

description: Steaks were fine. Why they would offer a lone non-prime NY strip is beyond me. Prices were $10 higher per plate than the value. The premium is due to it being essentially a hotel restaurant- connected to the omni, and I'm sure the prices are propped up by people on expense accounts. There is no steak house ambiance or any ambiace for that matter, much less any other reason that would be deserved of the premium prices. I think given the choice I would prefer one of the larger chain prime steak houses, which is something I don't say often. Too bad. There are just too many better places to go in SF (however poor the options in the fin district may be). Again, nothing wrong with the food, it's just not a premium steak house. And as a local, and someone who has visited many of the better steak houses in this country, i will not return. For the price, you could have an amazing dinner at any number of SF's prominent restaurants.
author: N. M.

description: Bob's is a relatively pricey but absolutely tasty steak house experience.  I have eaten at Alfred's, Harris and Ruth's Chris.  Bob is as good as the first two, better than the last one.  Wine list is reasonable, service was a little wacky but attentive.  One caveat, if you want a steak-y yet quiet evening, you may consider another location (such as Alfred's), Bob's can fill up with a conventioneer crowd looking to get rowdy in the big city.
author: Aaron F.

description: They never contacted me about this review, but I had some sliders at the bar when meeting up with friends, and they were great. But honestly the last experience was just so bad, and should have comped.
author: Danielle V.

description:
I probably should have ordered a steak since I was at a steak house, but I was feeling something light so I ordered the halibut, which turned out to be a disaster. Not only was my risotto undercooked and crunchy, my halibut was overcooked and very dry. The only thing on the plate that did not taste half bad was the asparagus.

This place gets 1 star for the amazing service. The waiter referred to me as "gentleman" when I ordered and when he offered to grind black pepper on my food, which I thought was a little strange, but nevertheless intriguing.

Also, 1 star for the bleu cheese salad, which in hindsight was probably the best thing I had there.
author: Jon H.

description:
Going to eat at a place with the same name as you is like a love hate relationship, you are either going to love it because it holds up to the demand of borrowing your name or you are going to be embarrassed to know of such a place that would try and be named in the same category, and that friendly reminder when people ask you that question, "oh do you own Bob's steak house", or oh I bet you like going to Bob's steakhouse". Trust me I get it all the time with having the name Bobby Brown and isn't nearly as fun as you would imagine....

Going into this fine establishment that is borrowing my name and the fact I had lost a bet and had to pay up by feeding two buddies who love to eat and rub in bets they have won didn't stand to give Bob's a very good chance of my eating enjoyment on Saturday evening.  We started off with one of the only ways to start a steak dinner with friends, with a nice cold martini which I must say hit the spot. My friend brought a killer bottle of wine so they took it for us to open it up and wait for us to begin the feast. They seated us in a small private room with a booth and gave us a very friendly waiter named George who was on top of it all night long. My friends were very hungry and ready to make me pay so we started with the shrimp appetizer, very good, a total of six shrimp prepared three ways, a little pricey for what you get however it was very yummy. Then onto the chop salad and the tomato salad both of which were also very delicious and in this case very decent portions for the three of us to share. 

Now it was it was time to start the feast and that is what we did, all three of us ordered the COTE de BOEUF which is their special 22 ounce bone in rib eye steak which was prepared as close to perfect as I could expect, not too fatty however the bone leaves it with great flavor! Of course my friends were going to order it up since I was paying so they also ordered two lobster tails that were ask for price and very very expensive yet very very good! We also went with the smashed potatoes which was a hard choice over the baked potato and the creamed spinach which I would have to say was my least favorite thing of the meal. We topped it off with some dessert wine which I was in the bathroom when my friend ordered so I am not sure what it was however all three were nice choices. 

Even with picking up this rather expensive bill, I must say the look on my friends faces and the pleasure I got to enjoy while eating this food and being waited on by George and his funny personality that I walked away a very happy man.
author: Bobby B.

description: I would give this place 4 and a half stars... it was TASTY.  I mean the bread to begin with was PERFECT.  Then I split the tossed salad with my friend and have to say the thousand island dressing here is where it is at....  For dinner I decided to get pork chops and smashed potatoes.  Talk about a quality meal and the wine that washed it down wasn't too shabby either.  I def could go back here.
author: ELIZABETH W.

description: If there is good steak in this city, its here ! There is a reason they say if you want to eat steak, go to a steakery? I have tasted a lot of meat around the world, best experiences have been in former SSR nations in central Asia (Fargana valley anyone?) and the steak here comes as close as it can to that mouthwatering taste of juicy meat that melts in your mouth and leaves you with that feeling of absolute bliss.....you know what I mean if you love meat :-).
author: Varun G.

description:
some of the best steak i've had in a while... accompanied by some great mashed potatoes and a fantastic tasting carrot.  shrimp cocktail is nothing to go crazy over, and neither was the crab cake.  all in all, very tasty, very filling, and service was extremely attentive and top notch.  

BUT...

i have a feeling that i couldve gone to any steakhouse in kansas city and gotten the same meal for about a fifth of the price.  

there's a magic formula out there:

food happiness level (out of 100) = magic number * dollars spent

bob's magic number was anything but magic :(

my wallet didn't particularly feel magical either.  well, i guess there was a disappearing act.
author: Jon Y.

description: shrimp cocktail was good. large plump shrimp. beefsteak tomatoes was well dressed and topped with tasty cheese. filet was nicely done and salted. the famed carrot stick was subpar - not a fan of the cinammon glaze. mashed potatoes were good, but way too much. brownie sundae was decent. very good peanut butter ice cream. brownie was just ok. went for work dinner, so i enjoyed it, but not sure it's worth the regular prices. just an overdoes of everything.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description: Great steaks and pork chops.......and the fish is outstanding too.  Best garlic mashed potatoes in S.F.  REASONABLY priced for what you get.  It is a neighborhood favorite now.  OUTSTANDING service and PERSONABLE wait and bus staff.
author: Larry L.

description: One of the top 2 steakhouses in SF in my opinon.  If you are in the mood to grab a flavorful ribeye, this is the place to go.  I have never eaten such a wonderful ribeye in SF than at this place.  Their appetizers are also wondeful especially their lobster bisque.   Only downside is that the ambience definitely does not  feel like you are in a steakhouse or restaurant to say the least.  However, food this good is worth overlooking.
author: Charles C.

description: Went last night and split the 12oz with Caesar and potatoes with the onions and gravy. I wouldn't order the potatoes like that again once I saw the baked version. The cow is great and with the split it was easy on the price. Staff was top shelf. The carrot you get will change you mind about vegetables. The bread is a great and they give you enough butter to slow your heart.  I wish they offered olive oil but oh well. Great place and the bathrooms will make you hang out at the Omni Hotel for a while. Take a date here so she thinks you have style.
author: Marcus B.

description: I can't say Bob's is the best steak I've ever had but their steaks are OK and I have yet to have anything on their menu that I'd call "bad".  The point is that if you go here, I don't think you'll be disappointed: the food's decent, the atmosphere is nice, and they have a respectable wine list.
author: David B.

description: Had a great business dinner here last night. the Fish of the day was a blacked Halibut with great mashed potato's. The service was average, the food was above average. The calamari was a great appetizer, and we loved the bread.
author: Devan R.

description:
This review is very dated, but I thought I would write it anyways.

I went to Bob's several years ago, when it first opened in the Omni I believe and I had the absolutely best ribeye steak I have ever had in my life.  It was perfectly charred on the outside, with the burnt crispy exterior complimenting the juicy fatty interior.  The service was also top notch.

I haven't been back to Bob's since then (I moved away and back to the Bay Area recently), so I don't know if the service and food are still the same, but I haven't quite had a similar experience to Bob's in SF or NYC since then.
author: Taylor W.

description: Bob's gets 4 stars for me because of its very convenient location to where i work, the speedy service, and the decent quality of food. I got the cod which rested on a bed of amazing mashed potatoes. I am sure mr fish was happy with such fine accommodations prior to ending up in my tummy!
author: Not M.

description: Went to Bob's in the Omni Hotel for a business dinner and left impressed.  Good steak house vibe, though not as dark as a steakhouse should be.  Food was solid and staff was on top of it.
author: Rocco W.

description: This is a great steakhouse - the service was very knowledgeable and friendly, their signature bone-in Ribeye is making my mouth water now just thinking about it... the lobster tail was off-da hook!  This is probably the priciest steakhouse in SF, but well worth it (supposedly #3 steakhouse in the nation).
author: Ricky S.

description: Got the chicken fried rib-eye steak with smashed potatoes. It was huge as other yelpers mentioned. It was good, but don't know if I would get it again. I enjoyed the sourdough bread and lemonade.
author: Louise O.

description:
UNDERWHELMED AND OVERPRICED

Typical steak house ambiance but that is where it ends.  The steaks were marginal steakhouse and the service was even less than margnal-it was almost non-existent.  

Too many other good steak houses in SF to waste time and money at this marginal (but in the middle of the financial district-so it is handy).  For dinner, go to Morton's near Union Square.
author: Bob L.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for the longest time and this past weekend I finally made my way.  Calimari was suprisingly good, but that was probably the highlight outside of the pinot that the waitress suggested.  I asked if the cows were grass fed and she didn't know.  The taste was decent, but both me and fiancee' didn't feel too good that night and the following day.  You could definately find better in San Francisco, ie. Morton's or I hear ACME.  The only saving grace for this location is the size of the servings.
author: Jason A.

description: Like what happens with Morton's, I love the STEAK of this steakhouse... But, the thing is that in this place, I don't feel like I feel at Morton's. When we went to Bob's our waiter was really rude and he didn't care a lot about our issues.. If it wasn't for the steak......
author: Maria M.

description: The food was excellent and George, our server, was very attentive. We enjoyed the experience. I suggest you take a fairly considerable amount of money with you since everything on the menu is ala-carte.
author: Lee S.

description:
I have never eaten at Bob's and my review is for drinks only. 

THEY HAVE THE BEST RASPBERRY LEMON DROP MARTINI! 

I love their raspberry lemon drop and come to Bob's for that reason alone. Make you sure you specify you want the RASPBERRY lemon drop. The traditional lemon drop is also good, but it's the raspberry lemon drop that I can't resist.  $15, but large pour and worth every penny.  Also, love their wasabi peas, nut mix. and sour candy balls.  Sounds silly, but they're quite tasty.
author: Katherine D.

description: We ate here tonight.  It was exactly what I was expecting. Nothing spectacular, but a solid, albeit expensive offering on the menu.  The hostess was very friendly and a great first impression to the restaurant. Two of our party had steaks and I had the pork chop.  The main proteins were all cooked exactly as ordered and were very good. The apple Sauce with my dish was wonderful and very fresh tasting, the onion rings side was great, the green beans side was bland.  on the plate the carrot that came with each order was far too sweet but alternately the skillet/peppercorn potatoes were wonderful.  Our waiter had great suggestions, but the server assistant pulled dishes before we were completely done and didnt offer to wrap anything.  overall I went in expecting a good experience that would be very expensive and that is just what I got.  I would go back, but there are definitely better offerings in the city
author: frank s.

description: Crab salad is good, sliced steak sandwich is excellent, if a little pricy.
author: Max C.

description: I used to work near Bob's and have been in on two holidays as well (unfortunately).  Skip the main dining room, it just doesn't work at all.  Old school hotel type dining room.  Wait staff is generally attentive but not very professional in my opinion.  Quality of the food in the main dining room is mediocre at best.  Forget dinner's at Bob's...it's not worth it.  There's better food at better prices in San Francisco.  Bob's is great for a martini lunch in the bar area.  In here you won't be disappointed.  If you aren't dressed like the typical financial district people you'll feel out of place though.
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: Now this is the place where you definitely need to use the expense account. I don't tend to eat much red meat, but if i ever was really hankering for a steak and was in the area and was willing to spend a hefty price for it, this is the place to go. Otherwise, if you don't want to spend that much, you can head to the bar for a nice stiff drink.
author: Pippi L.

description: There are a disappointing number of good steak places in San Francisco. But Bob's was good! I thought the atmosphere was really boring (it looks like an airport hotel) but the food was tasty.
author: Carson H.

description: Best steak salad I have ever had, not even kidding... Who said NYC has the best steaks?
author: Anthony D.

description: Really good food and service. For my fellow vegetarians, there is also a good selection of fish and salads. And the desserts are delicious.
author: Michele M.

description: As a lover of a good steak, I had the good fortune to experience the Bone In Rib Eye at Bob's. I have to say it was the finest steak I have ever eaten. It was perfectly cooked and seasoned, the taste was incredible. I have been to all of the top steakhoused and Bob's is now my favorite.
author: Randy L.

description: I have been to Bob's three times. Each was memorable. Each involved a wonderful T-bone. One of these legendary t-bones was the best steak I ever had hands down. The other two were close seconds.
author: Casey K.

description: Only average as steak houses go.  Not a very memorable dining experience.  Save the paycheck, calories, and big night out for Morton's instead.
author: K W.

description: A big, fat "meh." I work directly across the street and only go there like once a year - that should tell you something. I actually think the best thing on their menu is not a steak (also kind of a weird/bad sign for a steak place) - it's the dungeness crab sammy when in season. I find that big phallic carrot to be a very weird choice as a side dish.
author: Erica W.

description: We actually went to the bar & ordered filet mignon sliders, crab cake tacoes, & a mimosa.  The flavor on the sliders was good, but the texture was awful.  Everything seemed soggy.  My husband enjoyed the crab cakes.  The mimosa was flat-- probably because there was only a splash of champagne in it. Won't go there again.
author: Melly B.

description: I can't believe how poor the quality of the food was when I ate here yesterday.  We sat in the bar and I ended up getting the 8oz New York Strip.  It was (no exaggeration) probably the worst steak I have eaten that I can remember.  I thought the quality was more Applebees vs. a high end steak house.  The steak was full of grisle, flavorless and was not med rare as I had asked.  I actually thought I had offended the restaurant in some unconscious way to deserve such a meal.  If you come here order the burger, they are great and much more reasonably priced.  Skip the steak.  Not worth it.
author: Ken P.

description: This place is very sneaky because its located in a prestigious hotel in the middle of the financial district. Their food is pretty good, but their lamb very tasty and i love the carrots and potatoes on the side. The price is a lil pricey but its worth it once in a while. Great service and very happy with the experience.
author: Q W.

description: Went here for my Bday last week with friends. Got the filet mignon and halibit. Steak was pretty good, very tender and sauce was not over powering while fish was better then average. Appetizers was actually better then the steak and fish. Bob's is one of the better steakhouses in SF.
author: HUNG L.

description:
honestly, we've had much better food overall at other steak houses here in the city.  admittedly, the steak itself was tasty, albeit huge.  we both ordered the petit filet which was a whopping 9 ounces!  plus it came with a gargantuan serving of potatoes, and a huge glazed carrot.  everything else is a la carte.  we started with the crab cake which was one cake on a plate with a dijon mustard sauce.  it was ok.  then we split the cold asparagus salad which was not too bad but huge.  then our entrees, which we added the spinach and mushrooms as a side.  we ended up taking most of our dinner home because we were so stuffed.  no dessert.  

bob's is an old school steak house....on a monday night, it's all business dinners and guests of the hotel, in tapered jeans and white reeboks.  it's definitely not "trendy".  and i think there was one waitress for the entire place so service was very slooooow.   a decent place to get a steak if you're in the financial district.  otherwise, try bobo's or harris', or even izzy's.
author: Cyn B.

description: There is one of these in Dallas as well.  The food is absolutely awesome, the service is top notch, and the bar is big and comfortable.  The bathrooms have you walking through the hotel lobby, which is actually quite nice after filling your tummy up with 16oz of beef!  The carrots they give to you always spark a few jokes from the juveniles around the table...like me.  It is a bit pricey, but for a steakhouse, it is expected.
author: Pele N.

description: I have to say, I was a little disappointed. It's a good steak, but there are several better places in town. Beyond that, nothing was exceptional. Good, but not exceptional.
author: Justin C.

description: If it's lunch you seek, and $20-25 you intend to part with, there can't be many better destinations than the bar at Bob's.  Skip the bourgeoisie restuarant side of this joint, and sidle right up to the counter in the bar.  Chances are there will be no wait, and even the lunch fare lives up to the billing that Yelpers seem to be in agreement on.
author: Sam M.

description: This is my favorite place to refer steak eaters to.  I used to give this place four stars but they have since changed their bread loaf to one less desirable (think Costco).  I come from Texas and as you know the state is full of meat eaters and that's how I grew up.  I know a good piece of meat when I bite into it.  My favorite cut is the filet mignon.  So, whenever I go I love to order that wrapped in bacon, with mashed potatoes & gravy, the given grilled glazed carrot stalk, a shrimp cocktail, iceberg lettuce wedge with blue cheese dressing and a decadent dessert.  The creamed spinach is also a favorite of mine.  You can ask for private dining booths which is really nice.  The ability to walk in dressed in shorts and be able to have a fine meal is always nice too.  AND, here it comes - the place is really expensive.  Plan on spending about $65 a piece.
author: Mike Y.

description:
One word comes to mind: inconsistent.  The food is all over the place when I eat here, and that bugs me.  The steaks are tasty, but on multiple occasions I have ordered medium rare and received medium well.  I really don't like it when people screw with my steak.

Service is somewhat slow, but the wait staff is friendly.  I would argue that your time is better spent elsewhere if you are looking for a great steak.
author: Jason B.

description: Been a while since I have been here, but the food and the service were amazing.  Very good cuts of meats.
author: Allen M.

description:
First, I would like to thank the not-to-be-named business partner for picking up the tab. Respect.

Now, when we're through with that, let's get to the skinny. The place is created for one purpose only: to feed you 2 lbs worth of cow and free your corporate account of $100. Nothing more, nothing less.

The entire wine list is overpriced. $14 for a so-so local Pinot Gris?  P-leeze! The entrees are so homogeneous, it's not even funny. Your only choice is how well done you want your cow. They all come with a potato and one (!) giant friggin' cooked carrot. I ordered a piece of salmon (which cost $34) and asked for broccoli instead of potato. My dinner arrived on three plates: one for the fish, one for pound and a half of steamed broccoli, and one for the giant friggin' cooked carrot. Everybody else got the cow in the various stages of cookedness. No sauces, no imagination, nothing. Oh yeah, when they say "mixed greens" in their salad section, they mean the iceberg lettuce/shredded carrot mix that you might remember from your college cafeteria -- very poor choice for a salad that costs $11. The two deserts were lovely but again, very traditional and very large (a cheesecake and a key lime pie).

Bottom line: if you're Ok spending $60 per person and want to impress your sales people with the 28 oz fillet, this is the place for you. Otherwise, move right on.
author: Gina M.

description: we rolled in here from night of boozing and ordered a nitecap...manhattan's...made to perfection! who would've guessed! cute hotel bar, good service but this Manhattan was excellent! i would make a special trip just to have another one.
author: A.c. D.

description: Heavenly steaks that melt in your mouth.  I recommend the Prime Bone-In Kansas City Strip steak.  Yum!  The service was excellent, and the booths (if you can get one) are very cozy.
author: M S.

description:
B+
Located in the Omni Hotel at 500 California Street across from the sculpted metal banker's heart in front of the former world headquarters of Bank of America sits a handsome import steak and chop house that serves up an outstanding burger. A clubby room with white linen, fine carpets and great service, this joint knows good beef and uses the best here. They carry this thinking out with the best ingredients and fixings money can buy which makes this a good value at the relatively high price they ask for their premium burger. The meat is a generous, hand formed thick, round patty charbroiled or grilled to order, plated on white china and served with chilled fresh lettuce, tomato and onions, a spear of good pickle and a choice of high quality fries, salad or slaw.  Service is as it should be in a five star hotel that charges a premium for their food and ambience and the staff are attentive to details, large and small.

The fries here are worth noting as are the onion rings, and like I said it brings meaning to the phrase stolen by one of the fast food burger chains when they advertise their 'Whopper' which is a whisper compared to this huge offering.  Some of the other excellent choices here are salads that should be far more common in a city famous for seafood and fine dining like a variety of seafood salads, sandwiches and entre's, all pricey but generous and delicious.  It's a clubby, comfortable room with depth in their staff, and discreet focus on the things that make customers loyal.  A favorite for neighborhood professionals as well as sophisticated travelers, this is a great place for a great burger and a choice of some great beers and wines.
author: Stu S.

description: We too my sister for her birthday, and was fairly disappointed in the experience.  I suppose it might be because we look young(er) than the normal crowd, but service was not what I was expecting from a fancier steak house in an affluent hotel.  I had to ask for a refill twice before they brought it out.  The steak was okay, not as good as i had hoped, but it came with a giant glazed carrot...giant as in something bugs bunny could be seen munching on.  They also had a jar of pickles on each table as a centerpiece... I wasn't sure if we were suppose to eat it (as a tong was provided) or it was suppose to be decoration.  Either way, it was not appetizing to start a dinner staring at pickles in a jar...
author: Annie L.

description: Bob's is located in the Omni Hotel on the corner of California & Montgomery. I never thought a good steak house could be found next to hotel lobby. I was wrong. This place has a very intimate decor. The waitstaff actual know the meaning of "sevice". The New York steak I had was seared to perfection. Cooked perfectly as well (medium rare, of course). Also, if you like mashed potatoes, this is the place to be. They have perhaps the best mashed potatoes I've ever tasted.
author: Michael T.

description: I loved this restaurant so much that I went twice in a row  for my 3rd & 4th Anniverssary. We sat in the booth that was closed off from the rest of the restaurant which was really romantic. My husband and I had the porterhouse steak and loaded patato which was excellent. The food portions are so big that you will take half home.
author: Lenisha S.

description: Have been here many times, but my most recent experience left me lukewarm.  Met a friend for a "quick" lunch.  Waiter cracked weird jokes, and then managed to dump the entire pepper mill on my friend's salad.  Cobb salad wasn't nearly as good as I remembered. We couldn't get our waiter's attention for the bill for a long time, so the lunch was way too long and vaguely unpleasant.  What a shame.
author: Sandra K.

description: Good spot in the OMNI Hotel downtown.  Not quite as good as the locations in the Dallas area (i.e., they don't have the fried potatoes with gravy and grilled onions on them... yeah... it's a Texas thing).  Less frills than other SF steakhouses (5A5, Epic, etc -- why is that?  I always wondered why you would need to "spice" up a steakhouse).  At the end of the day, it's a very classy place with great ambiance and one of the best cuts of meat in the city.
author: Wayne S.

description: Bob's Giant Carrots scare me - but the food was otherwise good!  We went here on the recommendation of a prior dinner my fiance attended at this establishment.  He kept saying the chicken he had was good & prices were reasonable.  We sat down and ordered some drinks and awaited our server.  I peered down and nothing was priced below 29.99 for the entrees.  The 29.99 options were the pork chops, and some fish item.  Steaks started at 31.99.  No chicken on this menu! HA HA  We split a salad which was good, and huge plenty for two.  Then we each ordered the rib-eye which came with your choice of potato and honey glazed carrot.  The rib eye was good - but 30+ dollars good - questionable.  The Carrot totally freaked me out. A whole carrot peeled and glazed sitting on my plate.   I had a hard time eating it... why can't they cut the carrots up? One big Carrot (and by big I mean a road divider between your meat and potato) on your plate is not appealing.  The Baked Potato was like another other - expect the server came around with a caddy with sour cream, onion, bacon and cheese.  A fancy way to dress a potato - maybe this is why a rib-eye was 31.99??  OK and one last comment - what the heck is up with the jars of pickles and stuff in the middle of the table with tongs? It's SO weird.....  I didn't see a single person eating a pickle.... we opened the jar and closed it.  No thanks.  Our server was very nice & service was quick.  We didn't even have a reservation and they sat us right away.  The food was decent - the 3 stars is for the cost - a bit pricey for what it really is.  Two Rib-Eye dinners, one salad, two beers, and one glass of wine -was $113.00 and that's not including tip!  My wine was $14 dollars a glass & It was OKAY.  So while I enjoyed the service, the steak, and my date with my fiance, the prices would keep me from going back - that and the scary carrot!
author: J S.

description: nice place for steak house and the fried onion rings...but thebeef tomatoes i thought has meat in there but it was all tomatoes and onions still wonderfu. bar tener is not so nice but still doing his job!!!
author: cecille p.

description: I'm a big fan of this restaurant.  This place is in my top 3 for steakhouses in SF.  The meat quality is great and the steaks are always prepared the way you want it!
author: Nick H.

description: been here a few times and i always hang at the bar where the drinks and food come faster and i never have to depend on a quicker service.  but that's just how i am. ;)
author: Pickle R.

description: I probably come here at least once a month....very convenient since I work directly across the street. Service is fantastic and the food is always up to par. If you're going lite, try the crab cobb salad. Very fresh with a very generous portion of crab meat. They probably have - in my opinon -  the best burgers in the FiDi area so can't go wrong there when in doubt. These guys have the best onion rings ever...HUGE, crispy beer battered....as big as krispy kreme donuts!!! You'll love it!
author: Roger T.

description: Bob's Chophouse feels so midwest without any influences of San Francisco despite being in the financial district and inside the Omni Hotel.  The chops are grilled with easy flavor and tender and  they have the best crabcakes in my books.  The crabcakes are not the lumpiest as many people prefer but their sauce makes excellent, one of a kind.  I've tried the huge 39 oz porterhouse and lamp chops on different occasions and both were consistent in quality and preparation.  It's one of my favorite chophouses in San Francisco and the state.
author: Foodie B.

description: I've been to this restaurant twice and don't think I will go back.  Their salad was soggy and the dressing tasted like bottled dressing.  The steak was ok.. I mean, how can you go wrong with steak. It's either cooked the way you like it  or not.  I tried their countryfried steak for a luncheon and it's like diner food.  I wouldn't recommend this place.  It looks busy because it's in the heart of the financial district.  Food is blah.
author: Cj P.

description: Since my buddy and I were trying to find a place where we could get a good piece of meat and watch the NBA playoffs, we decided to go to Bob's.  In general, I'm not a huge fan of hotel restaurants and I dunno if I've ever been to a hotel steakhouse outside of Vegas so I wasn't sure what to expect.  I was very pleasantly surprised by my experience at Bob's.  As I was sitting at the bar, waiting for my friend, I discovered that they had Chimay on tap, which was a no-brainer for me.  I also had a well-made Belvedere Martini later in the night.  Since we were sitting at the bar, I was worried that we wouldn't be able to order from the full dining room menu but that wasn't a problem.  I chose the the 18 ounce Kansas City Strip.  It was a great piece of meat - very flavorful and moist and cooked to my specification of medium-rare.  My friend enjoyed his NY Strip too.  Although the steaks are pricey, they aren't out of line with what you'll pay at other top steakhouses in SF.  Plus they come with a choice of potato.  For whatever reason, all steaks also come with this gigantic carrot in the center of the plate which can't be substituted for anything else.  It occupies a good chunk of the plate and I was very tempted to remove it from my plate and throw it on the counter.   Also, the list of wines by the glass wasn't great.  However, other than these minor shortcomings, I had a great experience at Bob's.  I would definitely come back.
author: Saw T.

description: I attended a seminar in hotel housing this restaurant and decided to stop on by and sample the fare. It came highly recommended. I was hungry for dinner so I opted for an appetizer and some drinks. I had the crab cakes, I don't think they were that good, lots, of crab, but not exactly what I was looking for. They say Maryland style, but only Maryland does them Maryland style with luscious lumps of whole crab meat. Sigh, so that was a tad disappointing. Had a dirty martini and a glass of wine. I am NEVER going to do my world wide tour if I have keep having nights like this. Umm.  I think for what it was the price was moderate like 40 bucks. Maybe I have been living in the bay too long. Who knows! Gorgeous place, EXCELLENT SERVICE. Friendly, attentive and unfailingly polite. Dude you feel like a celeb or something. I was seriously sitting there thinking this must be how the other half lives. People going out of their way to make you happy. It made me vow to work harder on this damn LSAT, I want to be the top 10 percent. Nice looking older white men (all married), a good looking brit my age. Of course, you have the trash coming out for a night trying to shake off the dust from the trailer park, but hey, who am I to judge. I had a great time and the hotel offers wi-fi which extends to the restaurant. Next time I am getting the damn porterhouse, cause I'm worth it.
author: Jocelyn F.

description: cor de beau is the best steak on the menu, other than that , its not worth a try.
author: larry l.

description: If you like to spend needless amounts  of $$$, this is the place. Food was ok, but outrageously overpriced. We were seated in a dark, dungeon-like corner by the entrance. The young lady who seated us didn't even offer us a candle or lamp since the lighting was so, so dim. Our waiter was excellent, polite, attentive and the busboys were always checking for empty water glasses and empty plates to clear. Food was decent but small with a large price tag to boot. I didn't think a 9 oz. steak should set me back $47 and a scotch on the rocks almost $13. Our bill was almost $150 for two plates, two drinks and a coffee. A fortune! I naively believed that my being dressed to kill would've merited a better table, but no such luck. I glanced out of our dark "cubicle" to see guys in Hawaiian shirts and ultra casual attire seated at prime locations. Something was totally wrong with that picture. When I was looking for the bathroom, some guy in the reception area whistled at me and thumbed me in the direction I should walk to. Whistling at a man in a suit and tie? I thought that was reserved for hippies or the homeless. The BEST experience that evening was my wife and i being together on a long deserved date. Next time I think we'll go to our usual haunt: Houston's on the Embarcadero. Bigger portions, lower prices and an actual view...of people and scenery.
author: Al S.

description: This place use to be a lot better a few years ago.  Seems like they always overcook our steak, and also they've raised their prices recently.  Even the carrot doesn't taste as good as it use to :(
author: Cal H.

description: An out of town business associate wanted to eat here, and like all good Yelpers, I checked the reviews before going.  Perhaps I shouldn't have cuz most folks think it's pretty average and/or over-priced, so I was skeptical going into it.  Well, as usual, my fellow yelpsters were right on the mark.  I had the Sirloin steak, and it was delicious, but $50 when all you get is a carrot?  And what's up with the pickles and bell peppers as the free appetizer?  The house Cabernet was very good though.  I went on a Wednesday, so I assumed that the patrons would be old, grizzly, wealthy folk that were quiet and unassuming.  Wrong there.  There was 2-3 pretty boisterous groups that made it hard to hear the conversation at our table.  Made me wish I was with them!  I'm glad I went to check it off the list, but I wouldn't necessarily go back since it's rather expensive for what you get.  For my money, I'd prefer House of Prime Rib, or even Izzy's.....
author: Scott G.

description: Nice, but not great.  Nothing here made me feel wowed.  The steaks were good, very tender and juicy, but the carrot and potatoes were the best part of the meal, and IMO if you are a steak house you better make your steaks the best part of a meal.  For $40-50 a plate, I just expected a little more I guess.  Service was attentive, but a bit stiff.  Casual atmosphere was nice, and the bar seemed to be pretty lively.
author: James S.

description: Your typical expensive steakhouse, but you do get what you pay for as long as you order the rib eye. The carrot caught me off-guard at first, but it was tasty nevertheless. The new york strip steak was a bit disappointing, so just order the rib eye.
author: Jerry S.

description: Just OK. I'd read the reviews here and thought this would be perfect for a birthday dinner. We were sat in a tiny room off of the main dining room, not even music. Although our waitress was very nice, it really felt like we were a distant second priority. We waited 15  minutes before anyone came to our table, we had to ask for water, and 15-20 minutes between courses without so much as a busboy coming by. I worked in restaurants in NYC for 5 years, the restaurant wasn't busy enough to warrant this neglect. The food was only warm when we got it, presentation wasn't anything near the level the prices would normally command -  warm steak, potato, meager portion of veggies, all lost on this big white plate. Nothing like the photos.  I hope couple who goes there has a better experience for $189.
author: Chris D.

description: not bad, but pricey and the meat's not as tender as i'd like for medium rare.  gave me a slight tummy ache too after
author: Henry W.
